According to the federal government's own Canadian Advisory Council on the Status of Women, for every rape, which occurs once ever 17 minutes in this country, only one in 100 men are ever charged for the rape. The magnitude of the crime becomes even more apparent with the fact that one in every 10 men in prison are there for rape. According to a recent study in Nova Scotia, most rapists are sentenced to about two years and are back on the street in a year.
This is also very important: For every 100 cases where women do bring charges, 63 never come to trial, that is even before the case starts. For every 100 charged, only four are ever convicted and, of these, only three of the four end up in jail. You have to compare this with the statistic of a 67 per cent conviction rate for other crimes against the person. For crimes against the person generally, 67 per cent of the alleged accused are convicted. For rape, it is four out of 100, of which only three of the four ever go to jail. This says one of two things: 96 per cent of all women who press sexual assault charges are lying or our justice system is not properly handling this horrendous crime.
Certainly not for a minute would we ever believe that 96 per cent of women who bring these charges are lying. That is preposterous. Obviously it is the latter. It is glaringly apparent that new legislation, especially that which takes a new sensitized approach to the issue, is urgently needed. This is what we have in this legislation.
This legislation is being watched not only by Canadians, but by people all over the world who are struggling with this inequality against women, particularly in our urban centres. There has got to be fairness and this is what this legislation must provide. If this legislation does not provide that fairness between the complainant and the accused, it is not going to continue to exist. It is going to be thrown out by the courts and that would be very, very unfortunate because basically this is an excellent piece of legislation and very much needed.
It rests with all members of all parties in this House to make sure that we have the best piece of legislation we can get. It does not necessarily have to be one that we would like, but one that is going to work in the interests
Government Orders
of women in this country and in fact in the interests of all of society.
We need to protect women in our society. If we do not, the society that we value will crumble. If it crumbles, then what we have in this country, what we have prized in our justice system, and our sense of fairness will be gone. We as Canadians, men and women alike, will lose a great part of ourselves. We cannot allow this to happen when we have this opportunity because we have in place a system of justice that will make sure that we have the best legislation possible. We in this House of Commons should take the trouble to finely tune it to make it acceptable to the rights of both the complainant and the accused and what the judges in our courts feel is fair.
It rests with us to do this. I would hope that the government will be sensitive to the arguments put forward, that there will be the fine tuning that the minister says she welcomes, that we will be able to improve this bill so that we will have the legislation that can do the job in this society that we want to see done.
I hope that we can all work together on this, that there will be open minds and that we can bring forward the best legislation possible. I look forward to working on this and to have the chance to listen to the arguments brought forward and to do what needs to be done. If we miss this chance, we are certainly missing a chance not only for ourselves, but for women and other Canadians from coast to coast to coast.

speakerposition: Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext: Under Standing Order 74, the first two speakers had 40 minutes with no questions or comments. The third speaker will have 20 minutes plus questions and comments, but it is my understanding that there is unanimous consent to allow the hon. member an extra 10 minutes to finish off her speech.

Mr. Speaker, I rise today to support Bill C-49, the new rape shield law. This really is one of the most important pieces of legislation that this House has ever debated. This is the only piece of legislation that I am aware of that has taken into account women's lives, the perspective of women and how women feel about their lives.

April 8, 1992
Government Orders
I am very pleased to see a strong preamble. It makes it clear to judges who will be the ones interpreting this law in the future that it is designed to encourage the reporting of sexual assault. It is designed to provide fairness to victims as well as the accused and guarantee the equality of rights under the charter.
The preamble also states that the Parliament of Canada believes that a victim's sexual history is rarely relevant and that Parliament is concerned about the incidence of sexual violence and abuse in Canadian society.
There is one part of the preamble that I think could be more accurate and that is the section which recognizes "how sexual assault and particularly the fear of sexual assault affect the lives of the people of Canada.". It is actually women and children who are, as we have heard in both presentations in the House today, the victims of sexual assault.
One in four women will be sexually assaulted during her lifetime. Ninety-nine per cent of the offences are committed by men.
I really do not know any men who are afraid of walking on their own street or staying alone in their own home or afraid when their partners come home from work because they are afraid of being sexually assaulted. I hope that one day we can really say that the fear of sexual assault affects the people of Canada in that I see an increasing number of men who are afraid for their daughters, their sisters, their partners, their mothers and their friends. I see these men taking responsibility now for action to end this violence.
At this stage, I believe some women and men are complacent about the issue. They blame the victim and they do not want to think about it. This must change if women are to be safe in our streets and in our homes.
This proposed legislation defines consent. It says that third parties cannot give consent on a woman's behalf. What it is saying is, do not ask her husband, do not ask her pimp, do not ask anyone else. Only the woman herself can say yes or no. This is a huge step forward. It comes away from the idea of a woman as the property of a man.
The bill states that no consent is obtained if the woman is incapable of consenting by reason of intoxication or another condition. This has two effects. If a woman has passed out at a party it is no excuse to rape her. As one Northwest Territories judge put it, men just see a pair of hips and help themselves. Women will be more than a pair of hips under the law.
The other type of rape that can be prosecuted now is sexual assault against disabled women. We are all aware in this House of one horrible case of a deaf mute woman who kicked and tried to get away from her assailant. He was not convicted because she did not say no. She was physically incapable of saying no. Now men cannot rape a deaf mute woman and get away with it.
The bill also makes a provision for abuse of authority. A woman or child who is manipulated into sex by a psychiatrist, a doctor, a police officer, a religious adviser or anyone else in a position of trust can now testify against that person.
The profession should teach their members what is appropriate behaviour toward clients and what their legal responsibilities are. This law will make it altogether better and more sensitive and the services more sensitive.
I have been told about a lawyer who has said to immigrant women of colour: "If you will go to bed with me I will go to court with you". I have heard the shocking story of how a judge did not convict a man for sexual assault against a nine-year old girl because she did not protest enough.
I know what it is like to be a young girl of 11 and have a family friend make those kinds of sexual advances toward me. I know the confusion, the fear, the feelings of betrayal of trust of someone who is older, stronger and in a position of authority, someone you feel is trusted within your own home who tries to manipulate a child into an activity the child does not understand. That abuse is against the law.
The proposed law very simply states that if the woman or the girl says she does not consent, that she does not consent. The law says no means no.
It is the first time a sexual assault law is based entirely on the facts of the case and not on the accused's beliefs. The law now will clearly state that an accused's belief that the woman wanted it is not a defence in sexual assault. He also cannot claim that he was drunk so it was okay to sexually assault the woman.
April 8, 1992

Finally we are bringing sexual assault in line with other crimes. We cannot claim that it was okay to rob someone because we believed that person wanted to be robbed. We cannot claim that it was okay to murder someone because we were drunk at the time.
It is also very important that the bill states that woman can revoke consent. It means that yes does not mean forever yes, it only means yes until a no is expressed.
The bill states that a woman's sexual history is irrelevant to her credibility or to whether she said yes or no during the instance in question.
There is an excellent analogy with robbery. Just because you may have given money away in the past, it does not give anyone the right to take money away from you in the future. Just because you were wearing an expensive suit does not mean that you were asking to be robbed. Just because you invited a friend to your home does not mean that you deserved to be robbed by them.
Sexual assault is much more than robbery. It is someone taking a part of your body and your soul, a part which means far more than any property can possibly mean to anyone.
If you are a man try to imagine how you would feel to come home and find your house trashed and the things you worked so hard for gone. Think of how angry and violated you would feel. Multiply that one hundred times and maybe you can begin to understand how a woman feels to be violated in the most personal way possible.
The bill before us leaves it up to a judge to decide whether evidence concerning a woman's sexual history is relevant to the case. The judge will hear the evidence without the public or jury present and will decide whether it can be admitted or not.
My personal belief is that the sexual history of a woman is never relevant. I do not understand why if a man has a criminal record for ten sexual assaults that that is considered irrelevant in terms of his guilt or innocence in a particular case but that a woman's sexual history is ever relevant in a trial about a crime of violence committed against her. It does not really seem fair to me.
Government Orders
The Supreme Court of Canada did strike down the old rape shield law last summer and does believe that the sexual history of the woman rather than the violent record of the man is sometimes relevant.
This is why I believe it is essential for mandatory gender sensitivity training for judges and for lawyers on these issues.
A criminal justice system should be fair and accessible to everyone. We are living in a country in which the criminal justice system is feared, suspected and avoided by a significant number of victims of crimes including women, aboriginal people and people of colour. Fortunately, the complainant would not be required by law to testify at the private hearing in which the judge examines whether he believes the woman's sexual history is relevant. This avoids the situation where she would have to testify twice which would be once at the private hearing and once at the trial if the evidence is ruled admissible.
Some people do not realize how difficult it is for most women to talk about having been sexually assaulted. It is being asked to repeat the most painful experience of one's life in great detail over and over again to strangers some of whom will call the victim a liar, crazy, unreliable or deserving of the greatest emotional pain one human being can inflict upon another.
The defence would not be able to use the voir dire as a means to harass the woman by making her testify and wearing her down even if the sexual history is ruled inadmissible.
The media would not be able to broadcast the details of a woman's sexual history that would come out of a private hearing. This would prevent a jury from hearing about it unless it is ruled admissible. It would also prevent the woman from trying to drop the case out of embarrassment and harassment on the part of elements of the public.
Some men do feel threatened by this proposed law. As one male lawyer put it, he feels that the law makes seduction a crime. This particular comment is very instructive. What some men might call seduction many women know as rape. Men who respect women have nothing to fear in any shape or form from this law. Only men who force themselves on women, who do not care what women feel or think, who think that they have some God-given right to have sex with any woman that

April 8, 1992
Government Orders
they choose and at any time. Those are the men who can be prosecuted under this law and it is about time.
I believe that most men are caring human beings who do not want to hurt women. I want other men to examine their behaviour in the light of this proposed law and think about whether the things they take for granted are in fact hurting women.
I have been a member of Parliament for over three years. During that time I have been asked to examine other pieces of legislation. This is the most clear, simple bill that I have ever dealt with. It is straightforward both in its intent and in its wording. Yet people who prefer the status quo that prosecutes the victim instead of the accused are trying to say that it is vague and misleading. The only thing that is vague and misleading is these people's assurances that they care anything at all about victims of crime. If they did they would not advocate giving the accused far more rights in this crime than in any other crime.
I was very disappointed at the attitude that was displayed in a recent letter that the Canadian Civil Liberties Association sent to the Minister of Justice on this rape shield law. They sent me a copy of their letter. The arguments that they used against the law show no understanding whatsoever of the nature of sexual assault. The letter talked about teenage petting and how sometimes no explicit consent is required for initial overtures.
When a man forces his penis into a woman without her consent that is rape whether it is a teenager or an adult male. No one is ever going to be convicted for a kiss on the cheek. If cases involving penetration cannot even come to court we are fooling ourselves to think that someone might be convicted for something like kissing and hugging.
We must not forget that most sexual assaults are not reported including debilitating assaults. People who think that the courts will be full of kissing cases are attempting to ridicule a veiy, very serious matter.
The letter goes on to ask to what extent do males and females make different assumptions about such matters? That is a valid question. We should be teaching our boys and girls the same things about what sex is and about what violence is. Boys should be brought up with a better understanding of female sexuality and what their responsibilities are.
Contraiy to what the Civil Liberties Association proposes which is to go back to the man's belief about what happened, the facts of the case can now be examined by a jury of men and women. The jury will decide, not the accused, whether a sexual assault has taken place.
We are talking about a fair law that is not based on either the complainant's beliefs or the accused's beliefs but on actual words and actions just like any other crime. Belief, reasonable or otherwise, is not a defence to any crime of violence. It is too bad that the Civil Liberties Association is unwilling to join the late 20th century on this issue. It is already difficult enough to convict on sexual assault because more often than not there are no witnesses. More often than not it is not even reported. More often than not the woman is not believed and there is no conviction.
We are talking about dangerous men who are allowed to continue to assault women because no one stops them. Death and injury can be prevented from convicting guilty parties the first time. It is barbaric and wrong to allow guilty people to go free because the law is only concerned about them and not about the victim and not about public safety.
This law is a balance between those things. For those who can only relate to the accused and see his side, try working in a rape crisis centre for two days and you will see the other side of the story. There are women attempting suicide who are at their wit's end because their assailant is free to rape others. There is no justice in that. This continuing practice cannot be defended by any fair-minded person in our society.
The CLA also said in its letter that the debate has focused exclusively on the interests of only one of the parties to the exclusion of the other. That is patently false. The proposed law states very clearly in a number of places that the law is to be fair to both parties. No one, including the Minister of Justice, anyone in this House of Commons or anyone in Canadian society wants to see a law which convicts innocent people. That is not what this law would do or I would not be here to support it or to vote for it.
I want to see a law which convicts guilty people. We have never had a sexual assault law which did that consistently. Conviction rates for sexual assault have always been lower than for other crimes.
April 8, 1992

Sexual assault is the most under-reported of all crimes for the reasons that have been mentioned. The former law which was written exclusively by men for men has not taken the victims of this crime into consideration. Some people actually think that women are prone to lying about sexual assault.
This really displays a silly and condescending attitude toward women to assume that they would lie about sexual assault any more than anyone would lie about any crime. Also the person more likely to lie about an assault is obviously the offender.
I believe that women are less likely to lie about sexual assault than any other crime. In no other crime would she be put on trial and her character and her honour ripped to shreds and offered up for the titillation of strangers the way sexual assault has been.
No one wants to go through that. Women who come out publicly as survivors of violence are often threatened, harassed and receive obscene phone calls. Sometimes they even receive death threats.
The Civil Liberties Association believes that the press should be free to exploit a woman's sexual history. It thinks that by the simple fact of not mentioning the woman's name in the media that her identity would be protected. Therefore it would not be at all embarrassing to her to have the details of sexual relationships that she has had to be broadcast across the nation, in the local papers and that this, in no way, would constitute a barrier to any woman coming forward.
The CLA should wake up. Stop thinking about this issue from only a male point of view, and try to see it from a balanced perspective. The CLA letter makes an erroneous analogy to the Donald Marshall case. In that case it was the accused who was unjustly treated. The accused was from a disadvantaged group.
In sexual assault cases it is the victim who is from a disadvantaged group and often from more than one group. The offender in sexual assault cases is, according to a study, likely to be white and Canadian-born. In sexual assault it is the survivors of this violence and the ones who do not survive who are unjustly treated.
I urge women and men who want a fair sexual assault law and who want to end violence against women to take action on this issue. I urge them to tell their member of
Government Orders
Parliament that they support this law and let the Minister of Justice know how important it is for her to take action on mandatory training for judges, lawyers and the RCMP on violence against women and on women's equality.
Tell your family, friends and neighbours that violence against women is always unacceptable. Challenge offensive attitudes about women and about sexual assault wherever they occur and whenever they occur.
We do not need judges or anyone else with power over our lives saying things like: "Rules are like women. They are meant to be violated". We must challenge media portrayals of women as bimbos whose only role in life is to please men. Women are humans with hopes, dreams and feelings. They have thoughts and whole and complete lives.
Let us tell the makers of films, advertising and TV programs that the bimbo era is over. Do not sit back and think that this law will necessarily be passed unamended. Ridiculous articles have already appeared in publications such as The Lawyers Weekly opposing this law.
Please, let us make our voices heard on this issue so that the parts of the bill will not be delayed at some powerful group's request. It is finally time for a fair sexual assault law and one that incorporates the rights of the accused and the rights of victims.
The New Democratic Party will co-operate in every way to ensure that this bill is passed quickly so that the women who are being raped every day in Canada will have this protection under the law.
The vision of a world in which women, children and men are safe from violence will not be realized within my lifetime but I dream of a world in which all women and men live together in harmony, understanding and respect. By supporting this bill I feel that we are taking a step forward toward that world. For my grandchildren, my grandsons and my granddaughters, I urge all members of this House to join with me and the New Democratic Party in strong support of this bill.
I want to add my congratulations to the minister for bringing this bill forward quickly, after the Supreme Court of Canada struck down the rape shield law that we had in place and for moving in consultation with a number of organizations and women's groups across the country in presenting this bill to the House of Commons.

April 8, 1992
Government Orders

speakeroldname: Hon. Mary Collins (Associate Minister of National Defence and Minister Responsible for Status of Women):
speakerposition: Minister responsible for the Status of Women; Associate Minister of National Defence
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, it is certainly a great pleasure as the Minister responsible for the Status of Women to join in this debate and to enthusiastically support Bill C-49.
It is a very important day in this Parliament and it is a very important day in this country, particularly for women, to be debating this issue before us.
My hon. colleague from New Westminster-Burnaby was talking about the old sexual assault laws and how they were written at a time when it was predominantly men in this Chamber. The laws were written by men, reflecting a male perspective on the law. Fortunately much of that has changed.
We now have women holding responsible positions, such as my colleague the Minister of Justice, the first woman to hold that position, and myself as Minister responsible for the Status of Women and women throughout this Chamber who now can play a role to effect not only legislation but have the positive effect that I feel this will have on women's lives in Canada.
I would like to add my congratulations, not only to the Minister of Justice but to members of the opposition, men and women, who have supported this bill, and to the many organizations that were consulted in the development of this bill for the input and the thoughtful approach that they have taken to it.
I can recall some months ago when the Supreme Court of Canada struck down the rape shield law. It really was a surprise. Many of us working in this field had thought that it would not happen.
The women who worked in women's organizations were quite thunderstruck when that decision came down. There was a great sense of: "My heavens, what are we going to do now?" This was really going to be a very bad situation in Canada, if women would not have some protection about having to reveal past sexual activity or what is considered to be very private information about their background, and what could possibly be the relevance of that in certainly the majority of cases? I know in my meetings with women's groups and women's organizations there was a lot of anguish.
As other colleagues have said in this House, the issue of sexual assault is one that is unfortunately much more widespread than most people have recognized. The facts are coming out slowly, but even the statistics that we have now do not reflect the reality of what is going on in terms of so many women in this country who have been victimized.
In 1989 we had 12,970 cases reported, but that is only the tip of the iceberg. It is so difficult to really get a handle on it because it is primarily through anecdotal evidence, but I am sure all members of the House, and particularly women members who work with women across the country, have heard so many of the stories themselves. I know that I have.
In talking with women, and particularly young women, they feel almost a sense of resignation, a sense of what would be the point of reporting it, because all that would happen is that they would be dragged through a court, they would have information brought out about their background, they would feel as though they were on trial yourself.
How could they possibly put forward evidence that would hold up in a situation like that, and they would bring disgrace on not only themselves but their family and friends. I have heard this so often from so many young women. They feel really caught. They have often said that the only thing they can do is identify him among their friends. They know that guy, the guy in their class at school who behaves like this and really pushes women into sexual activity they do not want to be pushed into but they feel they do not have any way of dealing with it.
One of the most important parts of this legislation will be the message it will send to society, to men and women alike about the appropriate nature for sexual activity, the response that is going to be required of both parties, the clear definition of consent.
In many ways, at the time when the Supreme Court decision came out there was this feeling that this was a terrible time, but so often there is a silver lining in every cloud. I feel that this legislation is much better, much stronger and will be much more supportive of the reality of women's lives.
April 8, 1992

It is not only by being able to enunciate quite clearly the circumstances and the grounds when information about a woman's past sexual history may be relevant. I would expect it would be a very few times, but there may be times, as the Supreme Court has indicated, where there may be relevance and ensuring that can only be done in the most appropriate circumstances and that the discretion is provided by the judge.
This legislation then goes on to address another very fundamental concern which women have been talking about for some time but which had not been addressed in the previous legislation dealing with sexual assault, that is the definition of consent.
I wrote to the Minister of Justice and had discussions with her on this issue of consent. At that time it was not anticipated that this whole area of legislation might be opened up, but since it was being opened up it could be addressed.
The Minister of Justice has met with women's groups, heard their voices and has come forward with an approach respecting consent that very clearly changes the whole concept, very clearly sets out the parameters that there must be explicit consent.
We are talking primarily about men as was evidenced in 99 per cent of the cases. They can no longer say: "Well I thought she consented. She smiled and she said no. But she really did not mean it. We all know what that means". I am not joking. I hear this often. Or they say: "Well, my friends told me she was really easy and just give her a few drinks and that would be all that would be necessary".
The saddest things I have ever heard in working with disabled women are their stories about being sexually assaulted, sometimes by their own caregivers. It seems so astonishing to think that could happen, but it does happen. Depending on the degree of disability, they either cannot communicate or cannot physically take action to deal with that. They have felt so vulnerable and their world then becomes so narrow, so closed.
The other thing that is important to recognize as we discuss this issue of sexual assault is how it impacts on women's lives. I read something recently that said: "Yes, the physical wounds of rape are mended, but the psychological wounds in many cases are never mended".
Government Orders
Again, I know we can all speak from experience of women who have been through rape and other forms of sexual assault. It changes their lives in very dramatic ways. It takes away their sense of trust. It often confines them. In many cases, women deny it and find it very difficult to get on with their lives.
The recent report of the Canadian Advisory Council on the Status of Women Who is Listening, talked about young women. The statistics that were put forward in that report were quite shocking, about the number of young women who had been victims of sexual assault, some 18 per cent under the age of 15, 16 or 17 year olds and relating that to their sense of self-esteem and seeing the correlation and, indeed, seeing ever more dramatically that where young women had not reported the assault their self-esteem, their own sense of themselves, was even lower.
It is very important, if a woman is assaulted that she is able to report it and get the appropriate redress. She should have a sense of confidence in her community, in society and in the law that it is going to address the issue seriously. That is what this legislation does because it so very clearly sets out societal values around this issue. It will empower women to take control, in many ways, of their lives. It will have a very beneficial effect on men too.
I recall when the minister introduced the legislation and there were cartoons which had people having to sign documents before they engaged in sexual activity. That of course is not what we are talking about. That is carrying it to absolutely stupid extremes.
What I hope this legislation does is open up the dialogue between men and women so that they can frankly discuss their feelings for each other before they may engage in sexual activity and that young men are going to recognize that there is a very changed environment in which they live.
In the advisory council report there were some other, I found, very distressing statistics in the survey they had done with both young men and young women. The priorities of young men, and again we are talking about 15, 16 and 17 year olds, still relate to sexual activities. There were comments like: "I want to have sex before I am 16". A lot of their lives seem to revolve around that and that was what was important to them.

April 8, 1992
Government Orders
It was not a meaningful relationship with young women. It was just sort of physical sex without thinking about the implications of that with a partner. Obviously we have to address those issues. We know that people have hormones when they grow up, but how do they direct those kinds of virtues in fair and productive relationships between young men and women?
I am very pleased that the legislation is receiving support from all parties today. This really shows some tremendous advances for women, but also I think in terms of the whole legislative process.
I hope the bill will go to committee and have the appropriate in depth study that all legislation requires, but will be passed quickly so that we will have this law in place and then be able to work toward ensuring that it is implemented.
This legislation is but one step in the journey that we are all engaged in, in moving toward women's equality. Women's equality will not be achieved as long as so many women in our country and around the world live with the fear of violence, the reality of violence and, in many cases, that violence being in the form of sexual assaults.
There is much work that still needs to be done. Certainly my focus, as I address these issues, is ensuring we have the laws in place, ensuring we have the proper enforcement of those laws and the understanding of all the players that are involved: the prosecutors, the judges, the lawyers, the social workers and the court system.
My colleague, the Minister of Justice, is working very assiduously in that direction to provide that support. Beyond that, we then look at the whole area of education and prevention. How do we work with young people?
When we read the recent statistics on violent crime we see the incidents of sexual assaults as being a dominant form of violent crime among young people. This is an area that has to be addressed. How do you get at that? Through our educational facilities, through our schools, through organizations in the community and through the media.
I think all of us who have worked in this field have some very deep concerns about the kinds of messages which are constantly conveyed through the media with respect to violence, with respect to the roles of women and sexual relationships and how women are portrayed
so often in the media as being basically there for the pleasure of men. We have to work at changing some of those as well.
There is a lot of work to be done. Certainly the Canadian panel on Violence Against Women is one of the initiatives that this government has taken to address these issues. The broad issue is violence against women, but within that addressing violence within the home, public violence, sexual assault, abuse of women by those in trust, whether it is doctors or lawyers or in other situations. We are looking forward to their report and recommendations for what I hope will be a national strategy that can set out timetables, goals and actions that we, at the federal level, can be engaged in, along with our partners in provincial levels, in the community and the public at large.
We are not the only ones engaged in this. I met this morning with my colleague from Newfoundland. Newfoundland has just engaged in a new initiative relating to violence. The province of Ontario was announcing a program today dealing with violence and aboriginal women. The province of British Columbia just recently tabled the results of a very, very fine report that was done on violence against women. Many other jurisdictions are working on this and, as ministers together across the country, we are working as a result of the commitment we made two years ago at Lake Louise and reinforced last year in St. John's and will be working again at our meeting in Whitehorse coming up in the next couple of months.
Through the Family Violence Program of Health and Welfare there are a number of specific initiatives. There was one that was talked about in this morning's paper, a national study on date rape, an area in which again there has been a lot of discussion, but not a lot of objective study to really get at that issue. It really comes back to what I was talking about earlier, the problem of date rape where again so many young women are afraid to report it. They have been victimized in a dating situation, but often feel guilty themselves. They feel "maybe I did something or I wasn't able to take action". We are not only going to get a better understanding of that, but through this legislation we will be able to go out and talk to young men and women in their schools, in their colleges and say: "This is the law. Now, how are you going to work with us to make sure that people understand it and there is that dialogue and discussion and
April 8, 1992

support for this law so we do not have people breaking the law?"
It is an important time. Again, I want to congratulate the minister and all of those who have been involved. There is so much more work to be done, but for me it is heartening when I see these major steps moving forward with the support of colleagues throughout this House and I know throughout the country. We can in fact be agents of change here in Parliament, working together in a unified fashion, agents of change for the betterment of women throughout our society, but really for the betterment of Canadian society as a whole. I look forward to working with colleagues, not only in moving forward with this legislation, but with all the other initiatives that are going to be required to ensure that indeed women are free from the reality of violence and sexual assault throughout Canadian society.

Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to rise today to debate at second reading Bill C-49. It is not a lengthy bill, composed of only three sections, but the bill does address a matter of compelling interest and importance and even urgency in Canadian society.
It deals with an area where society, at least up until the last 10 or 20 years, has not had an inclination to discuss the implications of the changes in society as they relate to women and our criminal laws relating to sexual assault. I suppose 25 or 50 years ago there were a lot of men around here, not so many women, and there were a lot of things taken for granted, but not so anymore. At this time in our history, I hope we can continue the good work of discussing these issues publicly in the media, in Parliament, in our schools and elsewhere in society. As a consequence of the fact that many of these laws were put in place in Canada 75 or 100 years ago, there continues to exist in our Criminal Code a number of older laws with older attitudes as a foundation, and there are some considerable inequities.
Here today we have one of these inequities. Actually Parliament has tried to deal with it over the last 10 years, unsuccessfully as it turned out, as I will get to in my remarks.
Here we are dealing with the matter of sexual assault again and the law still needs updating. We have been using band-aids in the Criminal Code to update it for a
Government Orders
long time and I look forward to a comprehensive Criminal Code reform. The justice minister has made reference to it over the last while. I do not know whether this government will have an opportunity to get to it in this Parliament. I hope it will. If it does not, I can assure the House that a new government will.
A few years ago Parliament decided to amend the law and procedure governing the area of sexual assault. It did so to protect the interests of the complainant. In many public trials complainants were being humiliated and dragged through public trials when they themselves were the innocent victims. They were not the accused and that was an intolerable circumstance. Parliament attempted to respond.
In most of those trials, I guess all of them practically speaking, the accused were male. There might have been the odd one where that was not the case but for all intents and purposes the complainants who were humiliated were female.
Parliament introduced a new what is now section 276 and that was called the rape shield law. That law attempted to shield the complainant from that vicious and humiliating process of going forward publicly and providing evidence of a sexual assault in a trial of the accused.
However, recently, based on the Charter of Rights and Freedoms, the Supreme Court of Canada in the Seaboy-er and Gayne cases have struck down the section because in their view it prevented the accused from accessing and making a full and fair defence. Everyone understands that. However, it left this whole area wide open again. We were right back to where we started a few years ago.
Let us take a look at some of the context that we find ourselves in. My colleague from The Sydneys made note of it earlier, but the statistics on convictions for sexual assault are glaring when you look at the probability of a conviction here. Of 100 charges laid, only 63 ever got to court for trial. That meant that only 63 per cent of all of these sexual assault complaints ever got into a trial.
Of those same 100 cases, statistically there were only four convictions. That is pretty sad especially when you compare that statistic to the 67 per cent conviction success rate in relation to other crimes against the person.

Government Orders
We had and we do have a very serious problem in the judicial system relating to sexual assaults. That is the background we have. We are trying to make it fairer for the complainants who are usually female, not always. Sometimes they are children, sometimes they are male. We were trying to make it easier for the complainant to come forward.
There are probably several things wrong with the entire judicial package that is there. In this bill we are really just addressing one and that is the attempt to make it easier for the complainant. The bill attempts to make revisions procedurally and substantively to the elements of the law of sexual assault. The law will do three general things. It will put in place some guidelines for the admission of evidence relating to sexual history of the complainant. The guidelines will target the issue of relevance. It will become essential that any evidence that is admitted will be relevant to the issue at trial and relevant to the defence to the charge of sexual assault.
I note that is stated very directly in the preamble. I will speak about preambles shortly because it is a new process here, but the particular preamble that addresses relevance of the complainant's sexual history reads as follows:
- the Parliament of Canada believes that at trials of sexual offences, evidence of the complainant's sexual history is rarely relevant and that its admission should be subject to particular scrutiny, bearing in mind the inherently prejudicial character of such evidence.
If this bill proceeds, Parliament will have spoken clearly on the essential nature of the relevance on that issue.
The second thing the bill does, aside from creating guidelines for admission of evidence, is to create the procedure by which relevance and the other factors can be dealt with in a trial without prejudicing the complainant. Again, there is a preamble that states very clearly that one of the factors to be considered is the danger of prejudice to the interests of the complainant in this mini-trial procedure which will decide whether or not such evidence should be admitted.
The third thing the bill does is restructure and redefine the definition and concept of consent in the area of
sexual assault, because if there is consent, there is no sexual assault.
I would like to direct my attention here at second reading to four areas that I think deserve some attention. I do not want to pick the bill apart. I do not want to be even seen to be doing that. My party is supportive of this legislation. I think all of the parties in the House are. We want the best bill we can get. I do not want my remarks to be interpreted as not being supportive of the bill.
The four areas are as follows. We have to remember that this bill and the proposals here relate to sexual assault and sexual assault involves more than just the crime of rape. Sexual assault means all sexual assaults that run from near simple, if I can put it that way, sexual touching up to the more violent crimes of sexual assault and rape. There may be aspects of the law and procedure here that are going to have to be thought through for all of the various types of sexual assault, not just rape.
My colleague from the New Democratic Party placed very heavy emphasis and appropriately so on the offence of rape/sexual assault that is the most serious, that is the most heinous, that is justifiably the major target of the Criminal Code. There are other sexual assault offences. I feel we have to make sure that when we deal with this bill that we keep in mind that we are dealing with all types of sexual offences. I have a feeling, as I read the bill, as I listen to colleagues, that maybe not all of that has been thought through.
The second item I want to bring to the attention of the House, because I think it deserves further study at committee, is subsection (2)(e) of the bill. That is the section which deals with the definition restructuring of consent. It provides, and I am paraphrasing slightly here, but I think I do justice to the definitions, that "for the purposes of a sexual assault charge, no consent exists where the complainant by words or conduct revokes the consent".
That envisages a case where consent was given by both parties. Where one of them revokes the consent the law says that there was no consent. That means legally, during a period of sexual activity, whether or not intercourse has occurred and where the complainant revokes his or her consent, a condition of no consent is deemed to have existed. The result of that of course is
April 8, 1992

that the other party, male or female, has committed a sexual assault.
That was not the intent of the section. That needs further attention and it may well be possible to adjust the phrase and the definition in a way that will preclude an innocent party from being legally guilty or legally found to have committed a sexual assault.
I realize that men and women do not carry copies of the Criminal Code around with them all the time. When we cast a law we had better be sure precisely what conduct and under what circumstances we are proscribing the conduct.
The third point, which has been raised by others, has to do with the provisions in different parts of the bill dealing with intoxication.
In one part of the bill, we have the invalidation of the consent given by an intoxicated complainant. The bill says that it is not a consent if the complainant was intoxicated. You have the bill invalidating a consent and at the same time the same bill does not give recognition to the defence of mistaken belief by an intoxicated accused. There is almost a double standard here, and I think the committee needs time to think it through. There may be a justified double standard. There may actually be a very good reason to maintain those differences. At first blush, it appears to me to be inequitable to prejudice one party who is drunk and provide a benefit to the other party who is drunk irrespective of their gender.
The last item is an interesting one. It is a positive thing and I am sure the minister has gone through it carefully. It is the use of the preamble to assist the courts in interpreting laws passed by this Parliament.
Ever since the charter was passed almost exactly ten years ago, there has been some feeling of frustration in this Parliament and in legislatures around the country. It is the frustration that the courts may not be listening well or hearing what is happening in the legislatures and in the Parliament where our laws are passed. The courts are doing their very best to interpret all of our laws, both old and new, in light of the charter. That frustration is there.
The courts would like to be able to take account of the circumstances, the background and the intent of legislators, as legislators also have to deal with conflicting
Government Orders
rights and interests of all of our citizens. As we pass bills we have to do that.
This preamble approach may be very useful. I would like to refer to it as a pre-emptive charter-proofing, if I could use the term, so that the courts when they come to interpret our existing laws or the new laws that will have the preambles, they will know in advance precisely what our Parliament wanted to enact and why.
That may serve not only in the simple interpretation of the law but also serve in interpreting the different sections of the charter that permit a shuffling or juggling of the balance of rights between citizens.
I want to wrap up by indicating that I, along with my party, support the bill. I look forward to an effective committee study of this very important piece of legislation.

I said it the other day, perhaps I should not have, but my first immediate superior as a young lawyer was a Crown attorney in the city of Vancouver, a fellow named George Campbell who was a great lawyer. He also had two very distinguished daughters one of whom is the Minister of Justice in this House.
I was also a criminal defence counsel and I am tempted to get up and make a speech going into the details of this bill. Any good trial lawyer can go into the details of a bill and point out the difficulties here and there and so on.
I am not going to do that. I am going to approach it from a different point of view because I think this is the approach that members of the criminal defence bar, whom I hope will come before the committee and must come before the committee to deal with this, would take.
I am told that a Canada-wide survey indicates that 62 per cent of female sexual assault victims do not report assaults to the police. They did a study in Winnipeg where it was 87 per cent. Only 1 per cent of women report to police that they have been victims of an acquaintance rape, the most common type of sexual assault. I will come to that in a minute.
Various studies indicate the following reasons for not reporting incidents of sexual assault: 47 per cent of the women gave this reason, the belief that the police could do nothing about it. They said that they were concerned about the attitude of the police and the courts towards sexual assault. That is what the Minister of Justice was saying in her speech.
Fear of another assault by the attacker was the reason for 35 per cent.
Finally, the largest percentage, 64 per cent said it was fear and shame. Does that not tell us something about the inadequacies of the present state of the law when 64 per cent of the victims say that they are not reporting the assault on them because they themselves are fearful and shameful. Indeed, we seem to have a law in which we put the victims on trial, at least that is how the victims perceive it.
The member for New Westminster-Burnaby said an interesting thing. She said that this is not just an assault but it is a sexual assault. It is like someone taking part of your body and soul. It is hard for men to understand this in many ways. She gave an example or one of the other speakers gave an example. They did not mean to demean the assault by this example, but to amplify it.
I do not know how many members of this House have ever come home to find it has been broken into. That has happened to me about three times in Ottawa and I have lost some personal things. You feel as if you have been violated and this is only property. You feel dirty, violated. Somebody has been into your personal things and they are gone. This is only property. You can imagine what it must be like if it is your body. This is what victims of sexual assaults must feel. That is the way that we men can try to put ourselves into that position and look at it. That is the way we have to approach the bill.
I mentioned the Criminal Trial Lawyers Association. I think there is a lot of behaviour here that all of a sudden is being criminalized (and) it's a significant departure from some basic principles of criminal law-I think the fundamental problems lie in the redefinition of consent and the onus on the parties to sexual contact to confirm consent, creating I think an unreasonable burden on a person who wants to engage in voluntary sexual conduct to satisfy themselves of these standards.
This will be part of the position of the criminal defence bar. After all, its job is to make sure that people accused of a crime keep the basic principles we have in our system, that is the right to a fair trial, the right to the presumption of innocence, and the right to make full answer in defence. I personally, strongly and fundamentally believe that we have to fight to keep those principles.
What I am saying to Mr. Greenspan-and I say it because I am coming from the same place he comes

from, that is the criminal defence bar-is that let us have a look at the big problem first and then let us deal with the details to get a fair bill.
I wanted to continue the thrust of my point by quoting from some material printed by the Ontario Women's Directorate. It is called "Sexual assault, dispelling the myths".
True or false: Sexual assaults are most often committed by strangers. False. It is estimated that the majority of women, 68 per cent to 83 per cent, are sexually assaulted by men they know.
True or false: The best way for a woman to protect herself from a sexual assault is to avoid being alone at night in dark, deserted places such as an alley or a parking lot. False. Most sexual assaults occur in a private home. The largest percentage of these occur in the victims home. The next most common location is someone's car.
True or false: Men are the victims of sexual assault as often as women and children. False. It is estimated that 27 per cent or one in four are raped or sexually assaulted at some point in their lives. Of these offences 99 per cent are committed by men. The number of men who have been sexually assaulted is lower, roughly estimated at one in seven, which is an unacceptable figure. These assaults largely occurred to males under the age of 13 while women are sexually assaulted at any age. In approximately 95 per cent of the cases of sexual assault of men the offender is male. Regardless of the differences or rates of risk the effects of sexual assault of female and male adults and children are extremely serious and could be equally damaging.
True or false: Men who sexually assault women are either mentally ill or sexually starved. False. Sexual assault is a crime of power, control and violence. Men who assault are not sick, mentally ill or sexually starved. Studies and research on the psychological profiles of rape have overwhelmingly revealed that they are ordinary, normal, average men. We had better have a bit different definition of normal.
True or false: Only young and attractive women are sexually assaulted. False.
True or false: Women provoke sexual assault; they ask for it. False.

True or False: Even though a woman says no, she secretly enjoys being forced to have sex. False. When a woman says no, some men do not listen; they think she really means maybe or yes. I could go on, but what I am showing here is that there is a pattern. We are not talking about crazies. We are talking about everyday ordinary people. I say to the defence bar when it comes before the committee to focus on that. We are speaking about ordinary people who have not been made criminals before but who are criminals if they are committing sexual assaults. Society is now saying that it is going to change things. I want to say something about the Civil Liberties Association. I know it has already been spoken to. I have a high regard, as the House knows, for the Canadian Civil Liberties Association. I would prefer that we did not have to look at the past sexual history of the woman at all. It is totally irrelevant and should not be there. But the Supreme Court has said that it is still relevant and we have to live with that. That is what this bill is attempting to define and deal with.
There is some question about whether that should be reported. I have always felt that we should err on the side of the freedom of the press. That is my own particular feeling. I am a civil libertarian. I would want to hear them on this and I want to hear the government as to why it should not be. Sydneys said, why do we have a preamble? We do not normally have a preamble in criminal law. Maybe we need a preamble here to set out the new societal attitudes. It is a very interesting development. It will be interesting to hear the evidence in committee on that.
The definitions on sexual assault: Everyone has pointed out that it is largely women. It is defined in the bill as women, in the preamble and in other places. I would point out that gay men have also been victims of assault disproportionately. The committee may want to look at whether it wants to keep the definition just strictly as women.
Consent: We have to look at the issue of intoxication, whether you are drunk, whether you can consent, and so on. That is one of the most difficult issues. I have prosecuted cases, defended cases, and let me say that in criminal law the issue of responsibility or lack of responsibility if you are drunk, intoxicated or drugged is really a difficult issue. That has to be looked at by the committee very carefully.
If a woman says she does not consent, she does not consent. It says this in the bill. Is it such a big step to say that? It seems to me that would be obvious. It makes a lot of sense, but I guess it still needs to be spelled out and it will be in this bill. What about the problem of being impaired and then consenting? That still has to be looked at.

She has been very active in legal circles in Nova Scotia for a long period of time, serving Nova Scotia Legal Aid. We have that obligation to balance rights between all Canadians. An imbalance of rights has developed over the years in my opinion in the situation of sexual assault on women.
We have a court system that has been ruled for decades by male persons bringing all the prejudices and discriminations of the male persona to that and we have not taken into account the difficulties that women face in this situation.
I have experienced it as the member has experienced it. I have to admit that I have acted on behalf of defendants charged with various kinds of sexual assault and I pray to the very discriminating prejudice that exists within our court system. We have to right that. I am amazed that the Supreme Court of Canada showed such lack of insight in ruling out the existing law. I just want to say one more thing and perhaps the member will comment on it. We have parades across Canada by women who had the theme "Ihke Back the

Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to be able to stand in the House to talk about this particular bill and to congratulate the minister on bringing forward this legislation. In fact when the Supreme Court struck down what was called the rape shield law in its decision, I was one who said that it was necessary to bring legislation forward. It was not a situation which could remain within the common law, even though the Supreme Court had set out certain criteria and standards which had to be met before previous history could be utilized in court. I felt it was important that this place make a statement in this particular area and come forward with the criteria.

April 8, 1992
Government Orders
I was pleased to see the legislation. Of course we have to wait until the committee has a chance to consider it, but it seems on its face to have the right balance, to utilize the charter as it applies here, but also to utilize some protection for the victim.
The method that is used, which is not unique, but one that is not used that often, is a preamble. I think that is going to send the right message to the courts and to the systems particularly. If I can just read one part of the preamble, I think it drives home poignantly the point. It states:
AND WHEREAS the Parliament of Canada believes that at trials of sexual offences, evidence of the complainant's sexual history is rarely relevant and that its admission should be subject to particular scrutiny, bearing in mind the inherently prejudicial character of such evidence;
I think that sets the tone for this legislation and what we are trying to accomplish in this place. There is no question that an accused does have rights under the charter and that those have to be protected. At the same time, we have to go far enough to ensure that we are not victimizing the victims in these circumstances.
The bill provides three main elements. It provides for strict guidelines in determining admissibility of past sexual history. It clearly outlines the procedures that are to be followed and it defines a notion of consent.
All who have spoken today have said that no means no. It seems that a lot of people were functioning under the mistaken belief that no means something other than no and now we have a clear statement in the legislation that no does mean no. We are all pleased to see that come forward.
These defences of intoxication and the argument that what was said was not really meant, all of those sorts of things are now going by the by. In my view and in my party's view this is progress. This is moving the state of affairs between men and women one step closer to what they should be. There is still a long way to go but this is a positive start in that particular area.
I do have some concerns, and I want to point them out. I guess being a new member of Parliament, and only here for my first term, it is surprising when you look at legislation and you say it really looks to be pretty good and then once you get to committee and hear the different points of view and the different arguments from all sides, you start to think that well maybe you were a little stupid and did not really understand what was taking place and really missed some of the obvious holes in legislation. I am looking forward to this bill
coming to committee so that we can see exactly what is going on.
I do want to point out that there are some areas in the legislation that do cause me concern. One in particular is with respect to section 276(3)(h). It states:
(h) any other factor that the judge, provincial court judge or justice
considers relevant.
This is dealing with the areas of the criteria that the court should consider when deciding whether to admit evidence of previous history or not. What this can do, which is my worry and we are going to have to analyse it very closely, is put a discretion in the court and that discretion could be applied unequally across the country. It can create a major problem as to what a judge in, say, Newfoundland considers acceptable as to admissions on previous history, compared to what a judge in Victoria, B.C. may say.
We have to look at this paragraph to ensure that there are the protections, so that there is equality before the law throughout all of Canada and that there is not too large a discretion as to the admission of this type of evidence. Then I go back to what the preamble says which clearly states that this type of evidence is unusual and really is not relevant in most cases. While the Supreme Court has said that in some cases it can be introduced, I agree with my colleague in the NDP in wondering why it should be introduced at all. We cannot get around what the Supreme Court has said and so we will have to deal with it.
We have to ensure as well that the evidence, to a degree, is private. I know there are two sides to that coin. We have all seen the publicized trials in the United States; the Senate hearings in the Thomas case and also in the Kennedy case in Florida. We can see how publicity damages everyone and so I wonder where we can strike the balance in that regard. We will have to hear evidence with respect to this and bring it forward from the committee after we have had a chance to really study it in very close detail.
There is something else that we have to look at. It is a terrible anomaly that previous history of sexual conduct is still going to be introduced after a hearing, but the evidence of previous convictions of a rapist is not. One wonders why that inconsistency is there, particularly when you hear of cases like the Takahashi case out west in which there was not evidence, but an indication that perhaps 100 or 125 rapes had occurred even though he was only charged and convicted on four instances. None of those other cases could be introduced at trial. The accused is being well protected in that regard, but I am
April 8, 1992

not sure whether the victims are receiving the same type of protection.
As I say, we have to be careful not to victimize the victim. I do not think that became any more clear to me than on the justice and solicitor general's committee. I was before the victims of the Takahashi rape situation and at that time, the witnesses were testifying that they have all kinds of problems. They have the problems of what happens right at the instance because the first people they deal with are the police and the first thing they do is rush them off to the hospital and put them through further indignities.
One of the witnesses even went further to testify that after she had been raped in her own home, months afterward the police just dropped a bag off with the evidence of the soiled sheets without any consideration for the victim.
All of these systems seem to be set up to victimize the victim and that is what we have to worry about. I think that we have to take that extra precaution to make sure that we do not do that.
It seems to me, and it does not really fall within the jurisdiction of the Criminal Code, but when a rape case has occurred, it is absolutely essential that with the police should go some victim's assistance so that the victim is accommodated right from the outset.
As well, we have to spend some time with our court system, with the judges, and make them more aware of exactly what is going on so that there is assistance to the victim all the way through the process because we have seen it time and time again that we are going to victimize the victim if we do not.
The introduction of previous sexual history is, in my view, a victimization of the victim because of what earthly relevance does it have to the incident that would be before the courts?
It will be interesting to hear the different witnesses who come before the committee and get their balanced view. I know the civil libertarians are very concerned about this type of legislation as are a number of members of the bar concerned that there is some prejudice to the accused. But I do not think it hurts at all to exclude that type of evidence and that is why I am pleased to see this bill before us.

Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to have the opportunity to speak on this bill.
It is a bill about power because rape is always about power. More importantly it is about all the reasons why our laws tend to emphasize the powerlessness of women in society generally, and traditionally and historically before the courts as well.
I want to talk about the feeling of powerlessness that is every woman's from the time she becomes conscious of herself. I think it is vital to understanding why this bill is so important to us and why it is so important to a society that does not want decisions made on who is strongest and who is most powerful.
I realize it is extremely difficult for most men to understand what this means to women, but most men have grown up from little boys knowing that they will be big, they will be strong and they will have important jobs.
Most girls have grown up from the time they were less than two knowing that they would always be smaller and always be weaker and never be as important and never quite count as much. Neither would they have money of their own. They would always clean up after everybody else and they would always be good little girls, because ii you did not, daddy might get cross. Mommy might even get cross if you were not good and daddy did not like it.
This is why as we grow into women, every day and every minute of our lives is regulated by the fact that we are women, that we are smaller and that we are weaker. Every one of us knows the way in which we plan every day, where we can go, at what time of the day, alone or with somebody.
I doubt there is a man in the House who approaches his car at night in a parking lot with the fear that a woman does every day. It is important for all of us who have to deal with this bill here in the House and in committee to understand that that is why this is so important to women. That is why we need to find measures to equalize our treatment before the courts.

April 8, 1992
Government Orders
This feeling of being powerless, of always having to be just a little bit afraid, is partly what leads to the kind of violence that we have become so much more aware of only very recently. It is what leads to the exploitation of women in a number of different ways around the world.
It is what leads to the exploitation and abuse of power over women as a universal phenomenon. It is why women tend not to report crimes against themselves as easily or as readily. They know that that immediately places them in a situation where again they are powerless, others are in control and they can be hurt more. The question comes up of whether a woman's past behaviour has anything to do with the rights of the accused in court. Let me put the question this way: If I have given money to friends in the past, does that give them the right to walk into my home and steal money from me? If somebody uses their superior force to say to me "Give me $50" and I give it out of fear, does that mean I gave it willingly? No, it does not. If I happen to be the victim of a robbery while wearing an expensive suit and $600 shoes and therefore advertising the fact that I was wealthy and open to being robbed, does that excuse the person who robs me? Of course not.
Only women, in the case of sexual violence against them, come up against these arguments and have to, as the victim in a crime, defend against what they did to cause it, how they gave some man an excuse to violate them. It is that simple. That is what we are trying to deal with in this bill.
The accused is very carefully protected from having his history used in court to in any way suggest whether he is or is not likely to have committed this crime. Why does a woman, the innocent victim of a crime potentially, have to be subject to evidence that she may or may not have or is likely to have or is not likely to have caused this person to commit a crime against her, a crime so violent, so intrusive that the results are with her the rest of her life? I know that is a concept difficult for men to understand. If your car is smashed, what kind of anger do you feel? If you walk into your house and your television has been taken or your silver has been taken, what kind of anger
do you feel? You can replace a television set and you can buy a new car, but you cannot buy a new self. Rape forever changes who you are, how you feel about yourself and how you feel about the world.
This bill is so important because it is sort of the ultimate expression of women's powerlessness in society. There has just been a report out on why there are not women in engineering. I happen to be married to an engineer, I have a son-in-law who is an engineer and I have a son who is an engineer, so I know a fair bit about engineers and I know a fair bit about engineering faculties at universities. There is a whole culture there that is ugly and offensive to the very nature of women. It is so totally male macho culture that no woman is comfortable in it. There are things like the now-gone greased pole at Queens. Tell me what woman wants to be an engineer when part of your initiation process is to expose yourself to filth, and I mean that in the most vile terms, believe me.
Why are there not more women in politics? We will not have the kinds of laws that make it difficult for women to get justice when we have more women writing laws. That is not that I would write better laws than any of my male colleagues in this House. It is just that I bring a different perspective to it, a perspective I think is necessary to complete our humanity when we create laws in this House.
Bertha Wilson said it best when she talked about the difference between how men and women deal with laws, why the justice system is anathema to women. The whole idea of winning and losing that is fundamental to our justice system is a male concept. It is a concept that is promoted by those who are bigger and are more powerful. It is not a concept that women are comfortable with.
I am being very open and honest about my feelings because this bill is about feelings. It is about whether women feel that having been violated they can turn to the justice system that is supposed to be there to protect all of us and whether they can turn to that system and expect to be treated with dignity and as if they were the victims and not the accused. I suppose it is not a perfect bill, but I think it is a good starting point.
April 8, 1992

I congratulate and thank the Minister of Justice for acting so quickly in getting something to the House. I look forward to seeing if we can make it a little closer to perfect when we deal with it in committee.
I would just ask everybody in the House to bear in mind that we tend to put so much more importance in our legal system on property than we do on people. It does seem to me that we get more angry and react more violently if our property is harmed or taken from us than we do if another person is harmed.
I ask us to think about that in all the laws we make and as we look at the reports in the media in court cases. Look carefully at where the heavy sentences go. It is for crimes against property, not for crimes against little children or women.
I hope that will be taken into consideration as we go through this bill in committee. It should be as tough as it can possibly be. It should do as much as it can possibly do to overcome the automatic powerlessness that women feel. That is the only way we will start eradicating this particular crime against women and, hopefully, eventually violence against women in its entirety.
