Mr. Speaker, I believe that concludes the debate, if I am not mistaken.
I just want to take the opportunity presented by questions and comments to say to all colleagues in this House who participated in this debate how grateful I am for their contributions. It has been an enormously valuable discussion. I think each individual has contributed; my colleague from Cape Breton-The Sydneys and my colleague from Port Moody-Coquitlam, who are the justice critics for their party, my colleague the Minister Responsible for the Status of Women, the member for New Westminister-Burnaby, the member for Ottawa West and several other members of the Liberal party who spoke.
I just want to say that I believe this is an historic debate. The record of this debate is something people will look back on years from now. It is the first time we have tried to create legislation that really reflects the reality of life as it is lived by women in a very explicit way and where, on all sides of the House, we have had people who recognize that, supported it, were comfortable with that. I believe that is a quantum leap for women. We
Government Orders
have much to do in terms of making progress. I know there is devotion to that goal on all sides of the House. I have seen this in the participation in programs on violence against women and in my colleague's blue ribbon panel on violence against women. There has been strong support for this all along.
I want simply to say that for me, as the minister, who had the opportunity to bring this bill forward it has been a moving and very touching experience and a very reassuring experience to hear the quality of this debate and to hear the candour and openness and the level of understanding that has characterized all of my colleagues, men and women, on this subject and I am very grateful for it.
This is a day that I for one will not forget for a long time. Thank you very much. I look forward very much to the work of the committee. I would be remiss if I did not say how much, as minister, I appreciate the work that members do in dealing with the nuts and bolts of legislation. I think members of the public often do not understand the kind of work that their members of Parliament do. It is not necessarily very glamorous, it does not necessarily get the headlines, but it is absolutely fundamental to making the kinds of changes that Canadians expect us to make.
I want to say in advance, thank you to all whom I know will participate in this and to express my respect and appreciation for you, and thank you for your support for the legislation.

Mr. Speaker, I just want to echo what the minister has said and to congratulate the member for Ottawa West on her speech today. I found it very important.
I just cannot stress too much what is important in this bill and the importance that the women in Canadian society attach to this legislation. I would hope that we will get, as I have said earlier, the opportunity to fully discuss this bill, as the member for Ottawa West has said, to change any flaws that may be there and to make it a better bill. I thank the minister for bringing it forward. I ask the member for Ottawa West if she feels that there is anything that she knows of that can be improved in this legislation, now that it is ready to go to committee.

April 8, 1992
Government Orders

I would just comment at this point, Mr. Speaker, to say I will certainly be watching the committee debates very carefully and contributing in whatever way I can.
What is important to me is that things have not changed that much in my lifetime. For my daughters it is not even that much different, but I certainly hope for my granddaughters that they will at least be able to see a time when women will live without the kind of fear that many women do now. I look forward to the committee debate and I look forward to making some specific comments on the bill and how we can strengthen it.

I would like to respond to the hon. member's speech, which was an excellent one, and also to what the Minister of Justice has just said.
I used to represent the riding of Vancouver-Kings-way. It was represented at one time before me by Grace Maclnnis. In 1968 she was the only woman in the House of Commons. She told me a little bit about what it was like being in the House, and what it was like for her in those days. This House has changed a lot. Canada has changed a lot in that period clearly. I am sure if Mrs. Maclnnis were alive today, she would applaud what the House has done today.
I am speaking on behalf of the member for New Westminister-Burnaby, myself and all the members of my party. We are prepared to now let the bill go through and go to committee and get a thorough and quick airing in committee.

Mr. Speaker, I would like also to make some comments on this historic day. As a woman who has had personal experience with this issue as well as the mother of a teenage daughter, I think that things have changed.
I know that my daughter's school has a program on date rape. No such program existed when I was in high school. I think that is a step forward. At least we are now talking about this issue. It is out in the public forum for debate.
I also will be following the committee's deliberations with great interest.

Mr. Speaker, I want to take this opportunity to congratulate my colleague for Ottawa West on what was truly beyond an indication of her feelings on the bill. It was heartfelt. May I take a moment? It is an important issue to all of us partially due to the fact that in my particular case I have two daughters who are six and eight. Nothing would make me feel more secure in myself and for my daughters if some short time down the road they will be able to avail themselves of their very rights.
What I would like to do is ask the hon. member for Ottawa West if she could respond to this particular scenario which we have seen over the years where few women have come forward to bring their assailants to court.
In this particular bill I wonder if the member for Ottawa West could explain or tell this House and the constituents in our ridings if this bill is going to avail women a greater opportunity to do what must be done.

That is a difficult question to answer. I think women have to grow to have confidence in the system.
Let me tell you something I did not refer to in my speech but I think it is relevant as to whether women come forward or whether they feel there is a caring, comforting society to look after them when they have been injured rather than one that is going to blame and further punish them.
I want to tell you how I feel when a comment is made in a totally female word that is clearly pejorative, for instance, of a member of this House. It is a reminder of every time you have been on a bus as a little girl and some man has rubbed up a little close to you. It is a reminder of every time you have been grabbed in a sexual way when you were powerless to resist. It makes your stomach turn. That is what one word can do to a woman when it is directed at her as a woman.
We all know what I am talking about. When I feel that way on the basis of one word, how difficult it is to go forward to a police officer and say: "I've been raped. This is what happened to me". Imagine. That is why 96 per cent of rapes never come to trial.
April 8, 1992

speakerposition: Deputy Whip of the Liberal Party
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to be able to stand here today and speak to the second reading of Bill C-49.
This bill was introduced in response to the August 1991 decision of the Supreme Court of Canada to strike down section 276 of the Criminal Code commonly known as the rape shield provision. As a result of that decision, aspects of the complainant's sexual history will no longer be excluded automatically from evidence in sexual assault trials and judges will be left to decide if such evidence is pertinent. The court decided this was necessary to ensure the accused's charter rights.
Although generally recognized as a theoretically sound legal decision, there was serious concern among women's groups, much of the legal community, and the Minister of Justice herself that the door would be opened again for questioning a female complainant about her sexual past. As a result, in December 1991 the Minister of Justice tabled Bill C-49.
Let me stop here and tell you a little tale of one rape case that I knew of. This happened 20 years ago.
She was a lady in her fifties. She was partially deaf and she had gone to her neighbour's for coffee. On her way home, which was maybe four houses away, a car stopped in one of the suburbs of my riding and asked her for directions. Or so she thought.
She walked up to the car. She was abducted. She was driven out into the bush, raped and left there.
There was no doubt, of course, that she had been raped. All I can tell you is the horror of what happened during the trial. This was just an ordinary housewife in her early fifties with no sexual past as such. She had been married and had five children.
At that time the questions of the lawyers defending the accused were such that, of course, this testimony was printed in the newspapers. They tried to leave the impression that because she had walked up to the car that somehow she had invited this rape.
It was an absolutely horrible thing to be a person in the community reading about this. I knew this woman and I knew that this was a totally false impression. I also knew that this lady had a hearing impairment.
Government Orders
All I can say is that it is such a very difficult time in anybody's life without having this kind of thing happening. This is even though, in this particular case, the accused were found guilty and were sentenced.
Subsequent to that, I guess, the laws were changed. Such evidence was no longer allowed and that kind of trial was no longer a problem. However, I will never forget that. I was a very young woman reading about that in the newspapers. It had affected me greatly.
What does Bill C-49 do? The proposed legislation has three main elements. It provides for strict guidelines in determining admissibility of past sexual history as evidence. It outlines clearly the procedure that must be followed in admitting such evidence. It defines the notion of consent to sexual activity.
Additionally, the bill contains a preamble which discusses the context and rationale for the legislation. It may also be aimed at providing justification from section 1 of the charter of rights for any consequential infringement of guaranteed legal rights.
The preamble acknowledges that Parliament is gravely concerned about the incidents of sexual violence and abuse in Canada. It recognizes the unique character of sexual assault. It wishes to encourage the reporting of incidents of sexual violence and believes that evidence of the complainant's sexual history is rarely relevant.
The Minister of Justice intends that this preamble will be used for guidance by trial judges and lawyers alike and especially to reinforce the fact that great discretion must be used by all parties when dealing with evidence relating to a complainant's sexual history.
An accused would have to make a written application to the court for a hearing to determine the admissibility of sexual conduct evidence. The prosecutor and the court clerk would have seven days to review the submission before any hearing to determine admissibility.
Such evidence would have to be of specific instances of sexual activity, be relevant to an issue to be proved at trial and have significant positive value not substantially outweighed by the danger of prejudice against the complainant.
There is a publication ban on all evidence contained in such a submission. Matters to be considered by the court in making a determination of admissibility include the right of the accused to make a full answer in defence, the

April 8, 1992
Government Orders
aim of increasing the reports of sexual assault, the potential of prejudice to the complainant's personal dignity and privacy, and the rights of all individuals to the full benefit and protection of the law.
These matters will be discussed and decided upon in a private hearing at which the complainant will not have to testify if she wishes not to.
Finally, the jury will be instructed that they are not to be prejudiced against the complainant after hearing the evidence. Arguably, the boldest aspect of the bill is its attempt to define consent. Women's groups and those who work in the field of sexual assault have long maintained that until the law deals with the issue of consent it would be inherently unfair to rape victims. After all, they argue, it is consent alone that determines if a rape has taken place.
Bill C-49 defines consent as the voluntary agreement of the complainant to engage in sexual activity. It also removes or limits the defence of honest but mistaken belief in consent.
The bill also invalidates consent obtained in the circumstances where agreement was expressed by someone other than the complainant, where the complainant was incapable of consenting by reason of intoxication or other conditions, or where the complainant engaged in the sexual act as a result of abuse of trust or authority by the defendant.
There would also not be consent where the complainant expressed by words or conduct a lack of agreement to engage in the activity or a revocation of agreement.
Bill C-49 removes the defence of mistaken belief in consent where that belief was based on the accused's self-induced intoxication or recklessness or wilful blindness. It also adds that all reasonable steps must be taken by the accused to ascertain consent.
The bill also places an evidentiary burden upon the accused's mistaken belief in consent.
The Liberal caucus has been supportive of the concept embodied in Bill C-49 since its tabling. We are anxious to see the bill in committee so we can examine the concerns of the major critics of the bill. One in particular
is the criminal defence bar which fears that their clients will have a difficult time building a strong case with the tightening of the "honest but mistaken belief" defence. And there is the new concept of securing consent and civil libertarians.
There has also been negative reaction to provisions that would invalidate the consent given by an intoxicated complainant but remove the defence of mistaken belief in consent from an intoxicated accused. We will work to examine this closely in committee to make sure it is just and will withstand future challenges.
Most commentators have been amenable to the new guidelines placed on admitting evidence of past sexual activity. There is more contention surrounding the idea of defining consent, however.
As mentioned earlier, women's groups have been supportive of the concept although guilty intent is usually necessary to support a criminal conviction. Many find the defence of mistaken belief and consent to be offensive in rape cases probably because it ignores the victim's feelings or behaviour during the commission of the alleged offence.
Before 1983, in the enactment of the original rape shield law, women themselves and their reputations, not the actions of the rapist, were most often on trial. Reports of sexual assault increased by over 127 per cent from 1982 before the rape shield law was put in place.
According to the federal government's own Canadian Advisory Council on the Status of Women, for every rape which occurs once every 17 minutes in this country only one in 100 men is ever charged. The magnitude of the crime becomes even more apparent with the fact that one in every 10 men in prison are there for rape.
According to a recent study in Nova Scotia most rapists get sentenced for about two years and are back on the street in one year. For every 100 cases where women do bring charges, 63 never come to trial. For every 100 charged, only four are ever convicted and of these, three end up in jail.
Compare this with a 67 per cent conviction rate for all other crimes against the person.
April 8, 1992

This says one of two things. Either 96 per cent of all women who press sexual assault charges are lying or our justice system is not properly handling this horrendous crime. If we are to accept the latter-

Yes, please. If we are to accept the latter it is glaringly apparent that new legislation, especially that which takes a new sensitized approach to the issue, is urgently needed.
I am going to skip part of my speech so that I can give more time to my colleagues. All I can say is that we do need a new law against sexual assault which will deal with the reality of the crime and its life-long effects on women who find themselves victims.

Mr. Speaker, I very much appreciate the statistics that the hon. member has injected into the debate this afternoon. They are quite horrifying statistics, speaking as a woman, but I think they also demonstrate that the criminal justice system is not necessarily the only system that addresses this problem.
A lot of public education has to be done on this issue. The independent women's movement has made a large contribution to this. I know that the public school system is now starting to get involved as well because of the incidence of date rape in the high school population.
I invite the member to comment on these other than what some see as peripheral agencies that are also injecting their views into this debate.

speakerposition: Deputy Whip of the Liberal Party
speechtext:
I believe that awareness is perhaps the best method of educating people. I would agree that many groups out there have fostered a better understanding of what really happens in these cases. Not only women's groups but all levels of society can teach people that one has to take responsibility for one's own actions, be they male or female.
I have one daughter and two sons. In my own home I have tried to impress upon my children that one must always take responsibility for ones actions, that one can never blame it on somebody else or maybe I did not know. If you do not know, you should always find out.
Government Orders
The more education we have for our young people and the more public awareness of this problem then perhaps the more easily we can prevent it from occurring, at least in the numbers I have been quoting. They are horrendous statistics.

Mr. Speaker, I want to say that I have spent many days of duty in this House from time to time. I must congratulate the Minister of Justice on her speech and her bill and must congratulate the spokesmen for the Liberal Party and the NDP on the excellent discussion that has taken place on this very important issue.
Mr. Speaker, I think you would agree that the openness of the discussion and the frankness of the views expressed here today are refreshing. If we are going to tackle many of the social problems this nation is faced with, we must be open about discussing them. We must discuss them openly with our young people and our own families. It is very important for parents to discuss these issues with their children so that everybody is fully aware of these situations in life.
I know that in the past history of Canada and the past history of society these issues have been so closed that they were never dared to be talked about in the home. You know what I mean, Mr. Speaker. Today the discussion in this House is symbolic of the openness of people in their discussions with young people. I think it is very healthy. I would like to commend all those who have delivered excellent speeches this afternoon.

Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to be able to participate today in debate on Bill C-49, the rape shield bill.
I feel this is a step in the right direction, but it is only a step. This law will only become involved when a woman actually reports a sexual assault. When we look at the statistics from the Canadian Advisory Council on the Status of Women, they tell us that only one in ten rapes are reported. That is very low, the 10 per cent that are reported.
There are certain provisions in Bill C-49 which I hope and I think will encourage more women to report cases of sexual assault. There is much that remains to be done to combat the serious problem of violence against women in general and sexual violence in particular. A lot of that responsibility lies not only with this legislation, this government or the courts, but with all of us. Only a

April 8, 1992
Government Orders
change in public attitudes will free women from the fear of violence, sexually and otherwise.
Sexual assault is one of the most common crimes in our society. According to various studies, a woman is raped in Canada every 17 minutes. One in four women are raped or sexually assaulted at some point in their lives. The figures are probably higher for immigrant, visible minority and working class women.
The Canadian Advisory Council on the Status of Women has told us that one in ten rapes are reported. Of those reported one in ten are charged. In four out of a hundred cases charged rapists are convicted. That is 4 per cent which is very low when we compare it to a 67 per cent conviction rate for all other crimes against the person, 4 per cent as compared to 67 per cent.
Clearly the emotional damage suffered by all women who are sexually assaulted is enormous. It ranges from suicide attempts to alcohol and drug abuse, to recurring nightmares.
Even the three out of four women who will escape that will never be raped, accordingly to statistics. They do not escape totally because the study tells us that one in two women are afraid to go out after dark on their own, in their own neighbourhoods, according to a 1990 Gallup poll. Many more consider the possibility of physical violence when deciding to go for a walk, to rent an apartment, to go shopping or whatever.
All these statistics and these figures may be dull, but they certainly point to a very shocking picture of sexual violence against women, women whose pain and fear are not dull but are very real indeed.
The picture of violence against women in Canadian society is a national sham, a national tragedy. It is something that we all have a moral duty to fight.
Bill C-49 that is before us today fills a gap left when the Supreme Court of Canada struck down the 1983 rape shield law. That rape shield law said in effect that in a sexual assault trial evidence of a woman's sexual history was generally not admissible in court. It was considered irrelevant except in certain exceptions. However, the Supreme Court struck that law down. The court argued
that the right under the charter of the accused to mount a complete defence was violated.
Bill C-49 therefore has been very carefully worded to make it charter-proof. I also want to mention in connection with this bill the low conviction rate that I mentioned earlier. Four per cent of charged rapists are convicted, compared to a 67 per cent conviction rate for all other crimes against the person.
In this bill before us there are basically two main features. There is a new rape shield law that I just mentioned. The other is the first-ever definition of consent for sexual activity. The new rape shield law confirms that in court an alleged rapist can introduce evidence of the rape victim's sexual history in order to suggest that this activity made her more likely to have consented to have sex with him.
Now that mirrors the 1983 rape shield law. A woman will again be protected from facing the humiliation of having her sexual history used against her in open court to suggest she is lying or she asked to be raped. A new section says that any discussion of whether her sexual history can be introduced as evidence will take place before a judge behind closed doors. These changes will hopefully encourage more sexual assault victims to come forward and to lay charges.
Turning to the definition of consent, the bill defines consent as voluntary agreement to engage in the sexual activity in question. A woman who first said yes then later said no is not considered to have given her consent.
This tries to eliminate the grey area in which rapists in the past have hidden. A rapist would argue, for example, that he was too drunk to have known that the victim said no. A Montreal man last year in fact was acquitted in the rape of a 65-year old wheelchair bound woman on the grounds that he was too drunk to have intended to rape her. Or, he would argue that he just assumed she consented because the woman was too drunk to say no. Now a man must take responsibility for his actions by taking all reasonable steps to obtain her consent.
This is important legislation because by placing more responsibility on the man the bill will hopefully result in
April 8, 1992

fewer attacks on women and a higher conviction rate in cases which do occur.
I certainly look forward to this bill going to committee. In closing my remarks, I hope to have an opportunity to speak in more detail later at some point on this legislation. I want to commend the justice minister for bringing forth this legislation. I caution, however, that this is really only a small piece of a horrible over-all picture. The responsibility for changing that over-all picture rests with each and every one of us.
I look forward to this bill going to committee, to being examined, and to ensuring that there is an effective balance established between the rights of the accused and the rights of the victims.

Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to have this opportunity to speak at third reading on Bill C-56, the spending control act.
No one in this House can be in any doubt about where the Canadian people stand on the subject of government spending. It is, after all, their money that government spends and they, understandably, can see no reason why governments should be any freer in spending their money than they are themselves.
Canadians are tired of endlessly rising government debt and the annual deficits that produce it. They want government to live within its means and they want the burden of government reduced. They want some assurance that essential public services will not be eroded by overspending on non-essentials.
They want assurance that there are limits to the taxes they will be expected to pay in the future. The spending control act responds to those wishes and provides those assurances. It imposes a ceiling on all government program spending four to five years from 1991-92 to 1995-96.
The ceiling for each of the five years is the spending projections set out in the February 1991 budget. The spending control act marks the first time any government in Canada has moved to impose legislated spending limits on itself. Combined with a variety of spending control mechanisms introduced as part of our expenditure control plan in 1990, the act makes spending controls more visible and easier to understand.
Under the act, the rules could hardly be more clear, with limited exceptions. If expenditures on any program turn out to be higher than projected, they will have to be offset by reductions elsewhere. The legislation rules out greater borrowing or higher taxes to pay for higher than projected spending.
The February 1992 budget was consistent with the spending control act. Future budgets will also have to be consistent with the act, or they may not be presented without, at the same time, legislation amending the spending control act. These provisions go a good deal further than comparable legislation to control spending in the United States, the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings Act or the Budget Enforcement Act of 1990.

April 8, 1992
Government Orders
The spending control act thus takes its place as a centrepiece of the government's commitment to build a stronger, more resilient Canadian economy by controlling the deficit and the heavy cost of servicing the public debt.
This commitment has in turn been a central part of the government's economic agenda since it took office in 1984. In the 15 years up to and including 1984-85, spending on government programs grew at an average annual rate of 13.8 per cent or 6 per cent after taking into account inflation.
As a share of the Canadian economy, federal program spending rose from 15 per cent in 1969-70 to 19.6 per cent in 1984-85. That is higher than at any time since the Second World War.
Consider the turnaround we have achieved since then. Between 1984-85 and 1990-91 program spending increased by only 3.6 per cent per year, well below the rate of inflation of 4.5 per cent during this same span. We have in other words cut program spending in real terms. As a share of the economy, federal program spending is back down to 16 per cent, its lowest level in 20 years.
Mainly as a result of rigorous control of program spending, we have turned the government's operating deficit of $16.1 billion in 1984-85 into an operating surplus of $11.9 billion in 1990-91, a turnaround of $28 billion. More than two-thirds of this improvement in the operating balance comes not from higher taxes and other government revenues but from restraint in program spending.
Although we have made significant progress, we still have some distance to go. We are still paying the price for the uncontrolled deficits and build-ups in the public debt in the free-spending years before 1984-85. Although the net debt has more than doubled since 1984, all of the increase, and again I emphasize all of the increase, and more reflects compound interest on the $200 billion in debt this government inherited when it came to office.
As a result, we are still running a deficit. It is too high and every dollar of the deficit and more is accounted for by interest payments on the public debt. In other words, we are paying for excesses in the past that severely limit our room to manoeuvre today.
If we were not carrying an excessive burden of debt, these are dollars that could be used to stimulate economic recovery to fund programs in a way we can no longer afford, or to reduce taxes further than we have. That is why we are taking the next logical step by legislating limits on the growth of program spending through the spending control act. This legislation will give Canadians the assurance that program spending will be bound by real, not merely rhetorical, yardsticks. It will help to ensure the deficit will continue to be reduced and the public debt decline as a percentage of the economy.
It should be noted that the spending control act does not stand in isolation from the government's other measures to ensure a stronger economy by putting Canada's financial house in order. The act specifically reinforces the expenditure control plan introduced in the 1990 budget and broadened in each of the two budgets since then. It complements the debt servicing and reduction account which will receive all net revenues from the goods and services tax to ensure that our medium-term deficit and debt reduction goals are achieved.
Taken together, these measures will help us to secure the low inflation targets we have set out, targets that have helped to reduce inflation and bring interest rates down. Spending restraint and deficit reduction will help to keep inflation and interest rates down. This in turn is the essential foundation for the sustainable economic growth, expanding investment and new job creation.
As hon. members are aware, the government submitted a draft version of the spending control act to the Standing Committee on Finance. As a result of the committee's recommendations, a number of changes to the draft act have been incorporated into the final legislation. I would like briefly to review the most significant of these changes.
First, only the major self-financing programs will be exempt from the spending control limits. The act does not constrain the most important stabilizer in our economy, the unemployment insurance account. In the case of three farm insurance programs-the Agriculture Commodities Stabilization Account, the Gross Revenue Insurance Fund and the Crop Re-insurance Fund-only federal advances to cover deficits of these three programs will be exempt. All other self-financing programs are now included in the spending control limits.
April 8, 1992

Second, the draft bill provides that any overspending in one year could be made up in future years covered by the act. As hon. members are aware, the act now specifies that any overspending must be recovered within two fiscal years following a fiscal year in which overspending may occur.
Third, the draft bill was silent on the question of what would happen after 1995-96 when the act would normally expire. The Minister of Finance will now be required to recommend in the 1994 budget whether the act should be extended beyond the 1995-96 fiscal year. In addition, if at any time of the 1994 and 1995 budgets the spending limits have been exceeded, the government will have to indicate how this overspending will be recovered under the three-year catch-up rule.

subtopic: CROSS-BORDER SHOPPING EXPORT AND IMPORT PERMITS

speakeroldname: Mr. A. H. Harry Brightwell (Perth-Wellington-Waterloo) moved:
subtopic: CROSS-BORDER SHOPPING EXPORT AND IMPORT PERMITS
speechtext:
That, in the opinion of this House, the Governor in Council should amend the regulations made pursuant to the Export and Import Permits Act to provide that importations under the authority of General Import Permits No. 1 (dairy products), No. 2 (chickens), No. 7 (turkey) and No. 8 (eggs) shall be subject to a mandatory 48-hour stay of the importer in the country from which the goods are imported.
He said: Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to speak on this motion today which I believe is important to Canadian farmers and to Canadians as a whole.
The intent of this motion is to make sure that people who are importing goods under general import permits must stay in the other country of origin of those products for at least 48 hours before they come back to Canada.
Private Members' Business
Before I proceed too far in this discussion, I want to make it clear what it is I expect to achieve from this particular motion. A motion such as this gives an opinion to the Government of Canada that it should take a certain action in the future. It is not an act of Parliament, it is not a bill that will go through our process of committees and back here on report and third reading and on to the Senate for Royal Assent and become law.
It is a votable motion which will have a maximum of two hours and 45 minutes of debate. The hours of debate will work through our Private Members' Business routine and each hour may be separated by two or three weeks of House sitting time, so the final day of debate and the vote on this particular motion could occur in June or perhaps even later than that in this particular year.
This is a motion whereby the Parliament of Canada passes on its advice to the Government of Canada. While far from binding on the government, the passage of a motion such as this will be an opinion hard to ignore. If in the course of time the government accepts the advice, then this motion will have its desired effect.
I have noted in previous debates that our citizens are not reminded about our complicated processes and they often wonder about things that happen. In fact, observers of a supply day proceedings have become very irritated because they did not understand what was occurring. I hope this little explanation will put this motion in its proper perspective.
We have recently had on the Hill thousands of farmers concerned about the GATT negotiations and about the effects of a proposed agreement that was put forward. My motion today addresses a smaller but growing problem for many of these same people. These are the farmers working under supply managed systems and they number about some 32,000 dairy farmers across Canada and 3,000 poultry producers.
My motion would also make significant progress in reducing day shopping trips across our borders. Day trips are taking billions of dollars out of the hands of Canadian retailers.
Our first supply managed system began in Ontario about 26 years ago. I can remember that prior to that time, as a veterinarian, how the farmers were always

April 8, 1992
Private Members' Business
subject to the whims of the bottlers. They would upgrade their buildings, they would provide milk for the fluid market. Fluid is the milk we drink. Then for some reason the bottler would decide they were not good enough and would skim off to somebody else and leave the farmers in the lurch and they would have to sell their milk for industrial purposes at a much lower price.
In 1965 the then Ontario minister of agriculture, the late Hon. William Stewart, worked out a system of supply management. Since that day systems have developed for industrial milk, that is milk used for cheese or butter; eggs; chicken, meaning broiler meat; turkey and the last of the agencies was broiler for hatching eggs.
The supply managed systems worked by controlling production and imports. By the use of global import quotas, levels of imports for some supply managed products are held at a percentage of domestic use that is comparable to the average penetration at the time the system was put in place. Other products, like cheese, have a set amount of quota that has not varied for many years. Domestic production is then controlled around these imports so that the total of imports and domestic production is equal to domestic needs.
The access to our market is generous when one compares it to other countries. I believe we import about 2.5 per cent of our domestic needs of dairy products and this varies with the particular product. The U.S.A. allows only a very small amount into their market.
May I add here that our dairy industry survives very well on a very small federal government subsidy, small in comparison to other costs. It is about $225 million, but the supply managed farmer in Canada get his support from the market. In the U.S.A., it has been suggested recently that their government spends about $6.2 billion in support of their dairy farmers, nearly 30 times the amount of direct support received by Canadian dairy farmers.
Besides the access on the global import quotas, we also provide special import permits that are available for products when a particular type of supply is not available in Canada. However, even this very generous access to our market is now being significantly increased by imports through cross-border shopping. It is this problem that my motion wants to address.
Cross-border shoppers use what is called general import permits, sometimes known as GIPs, to bring in for personal use limited amounts of any of the main supply managed products. The purpose of general import permits or GIPs is to allow small amounts of milk, chicken, eggs or turkey to be imported to avoid the difficulties associated with applying our import rules. When GIPs were put in place, the question of crossborder shopping was a veiy small one, probably because our dollar was lower in value, our gasoline was less expensive and perhaps the psychology of cross-border shopping was not as deeply ingrained in the Canadian shopper.
Now all of these have changed and we have in the general import permits a growing problem for Canadian farmers. The change, as proposed in my motion, to provide a 48-hour stay in the U.S.A. before the use of a GIP would be a signal of support to Canadian farmers. As well, it would provide a significant boost to these troubled industries and would direct a large amount of business back to Canadian retail stores.
Perhaps I should say in fairness here that general import permits are the only method whereby casual importation can occur. If the GIPs are changed, as I hope they will be, there will be no opportunity to import these products within the first 48 hours away from Canada.
I want to tell members a little bit about how these general import permits are worded. No. 1, which is for dairy products, allows at each importation-and this could be several times a day, there is no limitation whatsoever as far as numbers are concerned-milk and milk products for personal use of amounts not exceeding $20 in value.
Each GIP or each general import permit is written something like this:
1.	This permit may be cited as the Import of Dairy Products for Personal Use Permit.
2.	A person may, under the authority of this General Import Permit, import into Canada from any country any dairy products for the personal use of the importer and his household, not exceeding $20 in value for each importation.
3.	Where completion and validation of a customs entry form is required with respect to any dairy product that is imported under the authority of this General Import Permit, that form shall be endorsed Imported under the Authority of General Import Permit (or the equivalent in French).
April 8, 1992

There are several other general import permits, but the three I want to discuss are No. 2, which allows the importation of up to nine kilograms of chicken meat per trip, GIP No. 7 which allows, among other things, the importation of one whole turkey or turkey products not exceeding 10 kilograms in weight and GIP No. 8 which allows a person to import up to two dozen eggs per trip.
I am sure that these limits apply to each person so I can see a family going across the border and each person in that family could bring back this amount of these products, multiplying the effect many times over.
The Government of Canada has conducted studies in recent years on the amount of dairy products brought into Canada by day-trippers to the U.S.A. Undoubtedly much more is also imported by people who stay for longer periods.
The results of the study which I will now quote-there will be quite a few figures here-are out of date because day trips have increased dramatically since even the last study in 1990.
Day trips were growing by approximately 20 per cent per year until 1991 when they grew by 10 per cent. The results I am about to quote could be up to 30 per cent out of date.
Agriculture Canada studies show that cross-border shopping for dairy products occurred even when prices were lower here than in the U.S.A., and I want to repeat even when prices were lower here than in the U.S.A. In each of the studies, I think there were seven different times that were studied, two times out of the seven, prices were lower here. That is something that many would not understand.
Maybe people do not understand that milk, turkey and chicken are often used as loss leaders, products that are sold at a loss or no profit just to get the customer into the store. Following this thought, the price of milk, chicken or turkey meat, or eggs might be influenced more by the need for customers than by the original price and would undoubtedly be higher the further away from the border that you go.
It is also a probable follow-up of this that border points would be an excellent place for American whole-
Private Members' Business
salers or retailers to have their short-dated products that have a lower value in the first place.
According to an Agriculture Canada study in New Brunswick in 1988, and this is very outdated, day-trippers imported 4.2 per cent of fresh milk, and .5 per cent of the cheese consumed in that province.
In southern Ontario, just the southern part of Ontario, in 1990 the study showed day-trippers imported about 1.26 per cent of fluid milk and .71 per cent of cheese consumed.
In northern Ontario the figures are larger, 8.29 per cent for milk, and 1.2 per cent for cheese. In British Columbia the figures were 7.6 per cent for milk and 4.5 per cent for cheese.
As I said earlier, each of these figures could be up 30 per cent and in the New Brunswick case because the study was done in 1988 perhaps the figures could be up as much as 75 per cent.
In 1991 it is estimated that 2.7 per cent of all the Cheddar cheese and 3 per cent of all the fluid milk consumed in Canada were imported by cross-border shopping on a day-tripping basis. Also one survey estimates that 2.7 per cent of the butter consumed was purchased by cross-border shoppers.
This is nearly as much as the significant penetration of our dairy market which we allow under global import quotas though indeed butter and milk are not covered under global import quotas.
It is also known that a great deal of chicken is purchased by day-trippers but the figures are not available. We do know that cross-border shopping accounts for approximately 3.6 per cent of all the turkey consumption in Canada and day-trippers would account for most of this. This is equal to the amount that is allowed under global import quotas for turkeys.
It is estimated through these surveys that anywhere from 20 per cent to 85 per cent of day-trippers to the States, and this varies depending on the locale that you are talking about, up to 85 per cent of day-trippers buy as much as 1.3 American gallons of milk each trip and about 20 per cent buy 1.25 pounds of cheese on each trip.
In 1990, using all of the estimates I have just quoted, and based on information in this little booklet supplied to me by Dairy Farmers of Canada called "Facts and Figures at a Glance" the day-trippers brought into

April 8, 1992
Private Members' Business
Canada about 10 million gallons of milk and 4.4 million pounds of cheese.
In 1992 based on the probable increase in day trips, this is likely 30 per cent higher, or 13 million gallons of milk and 5.7 million pounds of cheese.
In just these two commodities alone, we all must wonder: what does this large amount mean for Canadian retailers and Canadian farmers? Again my calculations from this little booklet suggest that these amounts are equal to sales losses for our retailers of some $79 million or $80 million a year in milk, and $25 million in cheese sales.
Undoubtedly many more millions of dollars in sales of other products are lost to Canadians because of day-trippers. Just the loss of fluid milk sales alone means that about 200 herds with an average herd size of perhaps 50 cows are no longer able to produce milk in Canada. Perhaps another 200 herds are gone because of other sales. I want to repeat that this is only for day-trippers importing fluid milk under GIPs. Much more comes in after longer stays out of the country and in other products.
I want to now admit that my calculations may be wrong, but they are not totally wrong. The fact remains that Canadian supply managed industries and Canadian retailers are being badly hurt at what best can be described as a back door method of importation that occurs through default or a process of convenience.
I want this House to endorse this motion. Before I can ask for that support, which I believe I have shown would be a great boost for Canadian retailers and farmers, I should probably discuss the implication of the end point of this motion on our trading agreements.
Supply managed products are on the import control list through a variety of laws which allow for supply management. As I have said, imports do occur through global import quotas or set quotas to an amount that approximates the average percentage penetration in years prior to supply management or indeed an arbitrary amount.
The provision of general import permits, as I spoke of earlier, are an exception to our border controls. They are largely for the benefit of Canadian day-trippers. Altering GIPs, as proposed in this motion, would not break our GATT trade agreements as it would mean a partial retraction of a privilege that is given. It is not a retraction of something in our trade agreements. I do in fact have excerpts of a legal opinion which I will read into the record here. The same legal opinion says that altering the terms of the GIPs does not offend the free trade agreement.
I will just read parts of this excerpt, because I am probably going to run out of time here in a minute. As compared to the free trade agreement:
Article 710 makes it clear that, unless otherwise specifically provided in chapter 7, Canada retains its GATT rights and obligations in respect of agricultural goods, including its rights and obligations under Article XI.
Nowhere else in chapter 7 are there references to matters affecting GIPs. In another part of this same opinion, it says:
Provided Canada has met its GATT, Article XI:2(c)(i) requirements, no further product need be imported. If Canada chooses to let additional product in,-
Indeed that is what we did with the GIPS:
-it is free to set the terms under which entry of the product will be permitted.
In this respect a close parallel can be drawn between GIPs and supplementary import permits granted for poultry and egg products that I spoke about earlier.
I want to close with this summary. Many thousands of people are making day trips to the United States in ever-increasing numbers, though that has perhaps slowed to a degree right now. One of the major reasons for doing so is to access markets where milk, poultry, turkey meat and eggs may be cheaper.
We know that usually these prices are held especially low on purpose to attract those very shoppers to the United States. I have suggested that if you were to look at true United States' prices you would find them much higher if you moved away from the border where lower prices would not entice Canadians.
General import permits were put in place before the present expansion of day-tripping and were put in place as a convenience for travellers and customs administration purposes. All of these products, by the way, are subject to tariffs. If you think about the calculation of a
April 8, 1992

tariff on a $20 item, back when the tariffs were 17.5 per cent, that would be about $3.40. Even then it was not worth doing the book work for it. Indeed, the tariffs are coming down under the free trade agreement making it less likely that anybody would want to take the time to do it.
The changing shopping patterns have turned the convenience of general import permits for day-trippers into a major pipeline of importation. The amounts, in some cases, are nearing the historical penetration into our market before supply management.
If my motion is passed and if the government accepts the advice of this Parliament, imports of these products should be greatly reduced since only those people who stay out of Canada for at least 48 hours will be able to avail themselves of this privilege.
My motion does not contravene the trading rules with other nations. It simply suggests a change in the terms of an exception to the rules of trade. While I am quickly gaining insight into the many aspects of this problem, it is very true to say that the debate has just begun on the matters of what I seek. I ask the support of this House for our farmers and retailers. That support can be shown by supporting this motion.

speakerposition: Deputy House Leader of the Official Opposition; Liberal Party Deputy House Leader
subtopic: CROSS-BORDER SHOPPING EXPORT AND IMPORT PERMITS
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would like to start by commending the hon. member for Perth-Wellington-Waterloo for the motion he presented in the House today. For the benefit of those who may not have read all the details, I would like to share the text of this motion with the House. It reads as follows:
That in the opinion of this House, the Governor in Council should amend the regulations made pursuant to the Export and Import Permits Act to provide that importations under the authority of General Import Permits No. 1 (dairy products), No. 2 (chicken), No. 7 (turkey) and No. 8 (eggs) shall be subject to a mandatory 48-hour stay of the importer in the country from which the goods are imported.
This is an issue of particular interest to farmers in Glengarry-Prescott-Russell and in fact to farmers across Canada. Some of my constituents are here in Ottawa today, and I wish to thank them for their support. I would also like to draw your attention to the fact that today, the Embrun farm co-operative's executive called
Private Members' Business
me to say it supported the motion, as did the members of the Embrun Chamber of Commerce.
The regional representative of the Ontario Milk Marketing Board, Mr. Gaston Levac, also called to ask whether I intended to support the motion before the House today. I certainly do and I welcome this opportunity to do just that.

Some people are perhaps still thinking that crossborder shopping is not a major problem in Canada. I want to tell you that if anyone still thinks that then they are in serious error.

I would like to mention some figures for traffic on the bridge at Cornwall, which happens to be in my riding. In 1988, 560,000 crossings were recorded. In 1989, this figure was 650,000; in 1990, 778,000, and in 1991, 1,400,000. People get on the bridge at Akwesasne to go to the United States. In 1992, traffic figures for the month of January alone showed 18,000 more crossings than in the previous year.
It is no coincidence, that in Massena, New York, a giant supermarket and a big shopping mall covering nearly one million square feet have been built to serve a population of 10,000. Of course, the whole point is to serve Canadians from shops in the United States, and the material loss to our merchants in Canada is incredible. In 1991, for instance, a loss of $36 million was mentioned for merchants in Cornwall alone, with a loss in tax revenue of $5.1 million, also in Cornwall. As far as gas is concerned, the figures show a loss of $15 million and a further loss in taxes of $6.5 million, out of a total of $340 million in retail sales for Cornwall.

Some people think that Canadian fanners are somehow making lots of money. That is a misconception. They are thinking as well that Canadian milk is much more expensive than it is in the United States. Of course that is wrong as well.
I will give some instances to prove the points I am making. I recently received a letter from Mr. William Howieson, of Knoll Top Farm Ltd., R.R. 1, Alexandria, in which he quotes certain statistics from a well known farm publication, Hoard's Dairyman. It is of course widely known to all farmers who are here in Ottawa today, as well as many members of this House.

April 8, 1992
Private Members' Business
Let me give some of these figures. Mr. Howieson states in his letter: "The 1990 New York business summary of 395 farms reveals that the total cost to produce 100 pounds of milk is $15.27. The comparable figure in 1990 for the Ontario farm accounting project of 204 farms was $15.32". That is only a five-cent difference in the cost of producing milk in Ontario than in New York State.
Those who think that our farms in the area are not productive are wrong, very wrong. In particular I must say that the people who wrote an editorial in The Ottawa Citizen last February 22 in which they said that farmers should face the facts and so on are wrong, very wrong as well. They do not know those facts and they should.
I also want to bring to your attention, Mr. Speaker, from the same farm publication Hoard's Dairyman, that a dairy farmer in New York State receives in direct subsidies double the amount paid to Canadian farmers. You do not have to be a Baie Comeau lawyer to figure out that it costs a lot less in the United States, not given the different cost in producing but given the different subsidy rate.
What we should realize is that this different subsidy rate does not even always result in lower priced milk in the United States than in Canada. However the consumer for whatever reason, principally because of the high taxes on gasoline and because of the GST, is misled into believing that many other consumer products are cheaper in the United States. First of all it is not even true sometimes, even if the GST in Canada is included. Nevertheless that perception is there.
To give a few instances to prove my point, I have here statistics compiled by Agriculture Canada on cross-border shopping dated November 1991. I want to give the differences in prices in milk in the United States and Canada at the retail level. In Prescott, for instance, the price of milk was $2.99 in Canada and $2.72 in Ogdens-burg. I do not think I would want to cross the bridge between Prescott and Ogdensburg and pay the toll fee to save a quarter, more exactly 27 cents. That is all the saving there is.
Between Cornwall and Massena, the Cornwall price for milk is $2.99 and Massena, $2,745 on average for four
litres. That is a difference of 24.5 cents. You do not pay too many tolls with those kinds of differences.
Consumers are not always well informed when they think that U.S. prices are much cheaper. Sometimes indeed there is very little difference, particularly in the area of dairy products. Nevertheless the hard reality is that many people are buying their milk in the United States.
The motion presented to us by the hon. member for Perth-Wellington-Waterloo would help to curb that.
I for one am glad to support this motion. It is my hope, notwithstanding the fact that we have five hours to debate it and this process could take as long as a month, that tonight, shortly before the adjournment time at eight o'clock, we could get a consensus of this House to adopt this motion this very day.

subtopic: CROSS-BORDER SHOPPING EXPORT AND IMPORT PERMITS
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I want to rise to support the motion before the House and to recommend to all other members in the House that they do so as well.
Our friend from Perth is attempting to point out a difficulty that has arisen probably not so much due to our border crossing rules but due to some problems that have arisen because the costs of our gasoline, alcohol and cigarettes are considerably higher than similar products in the United States due to GST, PST, excise taxes, et cetera.
What we have seen happening in areas close to the border is what has become a tradition for some Canadians: to spend some of their time off on weekends or time off work going into the United States to fill the tank with gas or maybe to buy some alcohol products or some cigarettes. While they are there the habit has been developed in a lot of cross-border areas of bringing back some dairy products or some groceries.
This has been a concern of some of the people who produce dairy products, eggs, chicken and turkey because they are working in a supply managed system where they force themselves to abide by certain rules, not to overproduce. In return for abiding by those rules, there have been limits to the importation of those products into Canada. These were spelled out once again in the proposals of their marketing plan, but there have been
April 8, 1992

some chinks in that process with the adoption of the Canada-U.S. trade agreement whereby Canada agreed to permit imports of turkey meat and chicken parts up to certain specified percentages that are laid out in chapter seven.
What we have been seeing, as has been described by the previous two speakers, has been quite a rapid increase in day trips into the United States. On their way back, they purchase gas, alcohol and cigarettes as well as some milk, eggs and cheese or perhaps some poultry. We have seen quite an increase in the amount of marketing that has been supplanted from outside sources as a result of these day trips.
It is estimated, for instance, that 27 per cent of the butter, 2 per cent of the cheese, and 3 per cent of the fluid milk consumed in Canada are imported by way of these day trips. No exact estimate is available to me at the moment with regard to chicken, but a certain amount comes in. As well it is estimated that about 3.6 per cent of all the turkey consumed in Canada comes in by way of day trips.
It is a question that affects a fairly large, though perhaps not yet significant, amount of the Canadian product that is out there for market. It does not just hurt Canadian farmers. It also hurts Canadian processors and Canadian retailers who miss that amount of business which could be done in Canada.
I know that some members in this House and some members of the general public may say: "This is only fair. We are into a new world order. We have free trade all over the place and people have to learn to adjust to competition". However, let us look at the facts in this case. In the case of dairy products some people may ask: "How come Americans don't come into Canada to buy milk?" The facile answer would be: "Oh, the price is a lot higher in Canada". The previous member shot holes in that. The price is really not that much different.
However, there is one thing we have not discussed so far in the debate, that it is illegal for somebody to take dairy products from Canada into the United States. The United States has maintained that right under article XXII of the GATT ever since the inception of GATT. For more than 50 years it has been illegal to take dairy products from Canada into the United States. With these dairy products that are coming in now, if the car turned around and was not unloaded of the groceries before going back, they would have to return them ironically to the Canadian side if they were caught.
Private Members' Business
There is a certain question of fairness involved here as well as just straight economics. The economics have been stated quite clearly by the hon. member for Glengarry-Prescott-Russell who spoke before me. Costs for farmers on either side of the border to produce dairy products are virtually the same. The Americans do have an advantage in having far more subsidies for dairy products than farmers on our side, but their actual production costs are virtually the same, within a nickel a hundredweight. The price of two litres of milk in stores on our side of the border is $2.99; on their side, $2.74 with the currency adjustment taken into account. For about 25 cents it really is not worth making the trip for the milk alone.
Most of the day-trippers make a trip to the States just as a tourist and to shop in a different environment. Retailers in the United States have certainly positioned themselves well to take advantage of this. My hon. friend from Glengarry-Prescott-Russell was pointing out the new shopping centre at Massena, New York, which services a relatively small area of New York has an awful lot of Canadian customers who make the thing profitable and make it work.
There are some differences as we move up the processing, retail and distribution chain in Canada that we see, however. This has been shown by a number of agricultural economists who have done studies on the so-called supply managed commodities in Canada. They have discovered when they compare Canadian practice with American practice that our processors and our retailers command much higher mark-ups for what they do in the provision of services and processing than do their American counterparts. That accounts in large part for the difference in price at retail between Canada and the United States.
The finger-pointing on our side of the border that goes on by people who speak for the processors and some of the chain stores would leave one to think that they are the biggest advocates of consumer rights in the country. They are simply advocating their own self-interest when they point their finger at supply management and at farmers who produce under a system of supply management.
They do not tell us that production costs at the farms here are equivalent to or in fact in some commodities slightly better than American cost in practice. They keep pointing the finger at those farmers on supply management and a system which permits farmers to get cost of production, a rare thing in this country in our farm

April 8, 1992
Private Members' Business
economic climate. As long as they are pointing at the farmer they are hoping consumers will not start looking at the bloated processing costs and mark-ups and the mark-ups at wholesaling and retail that we have in our country compared to what the Americans have in their country.
Granted we have bigger spaces to distribute food in. We have a smaller population. There are going to be some higher costs. For anyone who wants to get involved in arguing the merits of so-called free trade, some of the people who have been critical of farmers have missed the point. I think we should in fact adopt the motion before us. It would show that the House of Commons and members on all sides are in favour of a strengthened article XI and the continuation of supply-managed marketing boards and this change to the levies to day-trippers would show very clearly to all and sundry that this is our intention.

speakeroldname: Mr. Ross Belsher (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Fisheries and Oceans and Minister for the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans
subtopic: CROSS-BORDER SHOPPING EXPORT AND IMPORT PERMITS
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would like to, at the outset, compliment the hon. member for Perth-Wellington-Waterloo for his Motion No. 633 that he has placed before us this evening.
The motion really seeks to amend the Export and Import Permits Act to make it so that there is a requirement that a person coming into Canada bringing certain commodities that are under supply managed systems in our agriculture community would have to have been out of the country for 48 hours before the goods could be brought in.
This motion is seeking to advise the Governor in Council to amend the regulations to the general import permits that allow small amounts of supply managed commodities into Canada for personal use.
In my riding of Fraser Valley East and the lower mainland of British Columbia, we feel directly the impact of the increasing cross-border shopping.
Fraser Valley East contains a large part of the agriculture in British Columbia. That means in my riding there is the bulk of producers of the supply managed commodities in the dairy industry in particular, also some egg,
chicken and turkey producers. Supply management is very important to those of us who live in the Fraser valley.
Because we live right along the border, we are very sensitive to cross-border shopping and to its increase, especially for the same day shoppers who are bringing back milk, eggs, chicken and, of course, have filled up their cars with gasoline. Farmers from Rosedale, Chilliwack, Matsqui, Abbotsford, Agassiz and other centres are feeling the pressures on their livelihood that this cross-border shopping causes.
I know that this measure would affect these same day shoppers who bring those commodities into our country, but it would ensure that the spirit of supply management is maintained.
These general import permits exist to enable people to bring supply managed products into Canada in small amounts for personal use and to provide individuals with a special category or dispensation. In simple terms, these import permits are a regulatory way of making an exception to the general rule.
Let us look at why we have the existing rule, why we have in place a system of general import and export permits. This system allows us to make adjustments to the regulations that control the volume of specific commodities leaving or coming into Canada.
The general import permits are consistent with our commitments under GATT and the free trade agreement. Motion No. 633 simply wants to respond to a change in circumstances that is having an impact on supply-managed commodities and it is calling for an adjustment.
We have singled out dairy, egg, chicken and turkey industries in Canada as being special and in need of this special treatment. We have established a system of supply management in Canada for certain agricultural commodities because we are committed to the maintenance of a secure supply of domestically produced food. Canada needs to have a firm and consistent food supply.
For producers, we have removed the temptation to compromise on quality by taking short cuts on healthy farming practices. In return, supply management ensures that producers receive a reasonable price for their products. The fact is that this is the most open system
April 8, 1992

that you could possibly have. They have to publish what their costs are and then adjustments are made once or twice a year to the cost of production formulas that they use. There is no way that they can turn around and hide those costs from the people who do the checking in order to establish what their price will be.
This system works. This government is committed to supply management and has incorporated it as part of our negotiating position at the GATT. Cross-border shopping, specifically by day-trippers, threatens to undermine the integrity of supply management.
The B.C. Dairy Council estimates that the impact of cross-border shopping on dairy alone ranges from $120 to $150 million a year. This is in British Columbia only. This is obviously damaging to the dairy industry in B.C.
Agriculture Canada cites data indicating that in 1988, up to 7.6 per cent of B.C. fresh milk sales imported from the United States by consumers who had been out of the country for less than 24 hours. That was back in 1988. That figure is higher today than it was back in 1988.
In my riding of Fraser Valley East at the Huntingdon border crossing, a 1988 study shows that out of 1,464,440 vehicles crossing the border for less than 24 hours, 73 per cent purchased milk and 26 per cent purchased cheese. The average milk purchase was around seven litres. This is a significant problem.
The data I cite is three to four years old. This is an imprecise science and current data is difficult to obtain. This in itself speaks to the motion and the need for a higher degree of scrutiny. Industry projections that impact on quota and price depend on a sound knowledge of consumption in Canada and the source of that consumption.
When we realize the magnitude of same day crossborder shopping and its impact on supply managed commodities, we realize that we need to take action.
I believe that motion 633 is the action appropriate to deal with the present situation. The system of general import permits exists for this very purpose, to adjust to the changing needs of Canadians.
As the member for Mackenzie just told us, there are rules and regulations that the Americans use for taking dairy products in the United States. Why should Canada
Private Members' Business
not have a mirror of that or very close to mirror what their regulations are?
By requiring that those who import dairy, eggs, chicken and turkey into Canada to have been out of the country for 48 hours is necessary to protect supply management. If you are away 48 hours we are not limiting the ability of individuals to import these products for their personal consumption but we are responding to a significant problem in a manner consistent with the existence of our supply managed system. If we allow the integrity of the supply managed system to erode, we will defeat the purpose of the system itself. Therefore we must respond to ensure that the intent of the system in principle is extended to maintain the effect of the system in fact.
The Chamber of Commerce in my area tells me that it believes a great deal of the cross-border shopping is caused by the price of gasoline. I agree with them. Because of the taxes that we as a federal government have on gasoline and also the taxes the provincial government has levied on gasoline, there is a significant amount of tax on gasoline consumed by the family car. Nonetheless we know when there is a bit of a price war between the gas stations and the price drops down to below 50 cents a litre, it reduces the traffic at the border significantly, in fact, up to one-third when it is down to 49.9 cents. If it drops below 49.9 cents to 46.9 or 45.9 it is even more than that.
All of the governments, provincial and federal, should be seriously looking at how we can reduce the temptation for our constituents to find it necessary to go across the border.
I lend my support to this motion that we have before us tonight. This is a reasonable and responsible approach to a very serious problem. Time does not permit me to address the issue from the perspective of eggs, chicken and turkeys. Suffice it to say that the implications are similar to that of the dairy industry that I just cited.
The farmers in my community want to know why they are being hung out to dry. They are anxious for us to take remedial action so that they can get on with their life and get along with their livelihood. We know they are efficient. They do not have to take a back seat to anyone for their efficiency in the supply of their commodities.

Private Members' Business
The government is committed to supply management. I see this motion as a logical and responsible continuation of that commitment. I urge all members to support this motion and look forward to the timely and successful passage of this very important initiative.
I believe this responds to a large extent to the very people who demonstrated on our lawns a few weeks back, some 20,000 to 30,000 strong. It also speaks to the needs, particularly of the dairy industry and the supply management industry in the lower mainland of British Columbia.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I want to compliment the hon. member for Perth-Wellington-Waterloo tonight for introducing this motion into the House. By doing so, he has brought a very important private members' debate to fruition in this House.
He brought up the subject of cross-border shopping, of course, in all its reality. There are people crossing the borders to the United States to buy what they think is cheaper food and certainly cheaper gasoline. I would think that gasoline is certainly one of the big things that people go after when they cross the border, but there is another horrendous problem. That is the high taxation system in Canada. The GST was a big factor in promoting this, regardless of what anyone tries to argue to the contrary.
The high Canadian dollar hurts agriculture, forestry, and all natural resources in the country. When we have a supply management system here in Canada that we want to protect, we must use every advantage to do so.
I would say in all sincerity that the hon. member for Perth-Wellington-Waterloo has done more by introducing this motion than the entire government has done to help farmers in this dilemma. This is a more constructive measure certainly than any the Minister of National Revenue has come up with in regard to cross-border shopping and how it hurts the farm community. As I said, it is better than the Government of Canada generally.
I was concerned about and interested in some of the statistics mentioned by my hon. friend from Glengarry- Prescott-Russell. He was dead on on some of those. Canadian farmers can compete against anybody if you give them a fair chance. But they must have a fair deal, a fair deal base from which to operate. They are very efficient.
Gene Whelan, as you know, when he was Minister of Agriculture always used to say that the Canadian farmer can compete with anybody, that they are one of the most efficient industries in the world.
If big corporations were affected by some of the damaging financial arrangements by the Government of Canada such as those that affect the farmers, the board of directors would simply pick up its valuables and move south of the border. But the farmer cannot pick up his farm and move it elsewhere, nor would he want to leave Canada.
The feet of our farm community are planted firmly on Canadian soil and all our farmers and their families ask for is a fair financial climate within which to operate. Surely that is not too much to ask of your own government in your own country.
Some people are of the opinion that the family farm is going to continue regardless of the economic climate, regardless of the exchange rate, regardless of supply management, and on it goes. But you know, there is only so much that an industry can take when it is hit from several directions at once.
I must say that the farm community must have a fair deal base from which to operate. They do not need all of the above disadvantages as a challenge. Give them that fair deal and they will compete with anyone. The government's determination to keep the dollar high is indeed nothing short of an attack on Canadian farmers and other businesses.
On the price of gasoline, yes we all know gasoline is cheaper south of the border, but we also know that the American nation has something like in excess of a $2 trillion debt. They are living in a fairyland. The day is going to come when they are going to have to tax that gasoline and they are going to have to bring in taxation to Washington to balance their books or they are going to be the sinking empire of the world. They are living in a wonderland and the reality has not struck home yet.
I would like to follow up on something that my hon. friend from Glengarry-Prescott-Russell said a while ago about the comparative cost of milk on each side of
April 8, 1992

the border. At Landsdowne near Kingston, the Thousand Islands Bridge, four litres of milk costs $3.29. This is a 1991 Info Results Ltd. price. At Watertown, just across the border, it is $2.86, not a big difference when you have to drive that distance. I think Watertown is some 30 or 35 miles from Kingston.
Then you go to Windsor and Detroit. There is a very interesting figure here. The price of four litres of milk in Windsor, Ontario, is $2.49 and in Detroit, in Canadian dollars, the price of four litres of milk is $2.49. Exactly the same. You have to burn up the gas, take the car, drive across into the United States and go through the hassles of the traffic in Detroit to buy it. There is no advantage there.
I have said before that we are a great Canadian nation. A new national spirit is being born in this country. We have to look to the past when our Canadian farmers fed Europeans and the British Isles during World War II. The European continent has not been very kind to Canada in these modern days either. What we have to do in this country is develop an aggressive attitude. We have to bring in measures such as this very constructive one the hon. member for Perth-Wellington-Waterloo brought in today. We thank him for it.
I want to sit down because I know there is an hon. member across the way who wants to speak for a few minutes. I want to give him some time. I would hope that all members would sit down at exactly one minute to eight tonight so that this vote can be taken and we can get on with one of the most constructive measures that any government member has proposed, including the cabinet, on the farm question to date.

Mr. Speaker, I guess the debate tonight was whether or not I was going to have a chance to speak because we are running very close to the hour.
I do want to congratulate all members on both sides of the House on this important debate on this important motion. I think there are a lot of similarities in thought.
Private Members' Business
It is refreshing to see that we are on the same side of the issue. I think we all support this motion.
If the people back home really want to know what we are talking about, it can be best summed up by simply stating that this motion for the first time protects something we want. It is protecting our markets, our industries and in doing so is protecting our towns, cities and villages. It is a start to protecting the Canadian economy, something we have not thought enough about in this place.
Obviously on the minds of the countries we trade with is the protection of their economies, and they do a very good job of it. We are reminded of that and have been reminded of that often in recent weeks. We only have to look at the rules of origin that the Americans are attacking us on in the automobile industry, specifically the Honda automobile.
Yesterday we found out what they were up to in the softwood lumber proposal they threw at us. Again, it is a clever way to protect their own industries. We are not going to buy into that. What we do not want to buy into is anything that will jeopardize our supply managed industries, our supply managed farm groups. They are important to us and they are doing a good job. Again, I think it goes back to that old line I have used on occasion, that selling is teaching. I do not think that is something we have done a good job of in this country, teaching or explaining to Canadian people why supply management is so important. We have to do more of that.
